 This loss of faith in government accelerated in the wake of the Vietnam War, Watergate, the Waco deaths, the Oklahoma City bombing coverup, and the many unanswered questions about 9/11 .

 Dallas has grown from a small way station for pioneers to a center of corporate business, insurance, banking, and oil and gas . Dallas was founded in the days before Texas became a state, but has grown to a major business hub .
 By 1963, Dallas already was the most influential city in the Lone Star State, second only to oil-rich Houston . Dallas was the city's second-largest city, after Houston .
 Dallas also had a reputation for being a stronghold of archconservatives, if not outright right-wing extremists . Dallas had gained a reputation as a conservative stronghold in recent years .
 It is well-known in Texas police circles that if a man wanted a job as a Dallas policeman, it helped if he was a member of the Ku Klux Klan, or at least the John Birch Society .
 The city police and other governmental offices were filled with members of right-wing groups . Police and other government offices were full of members of these groups . The city was filled with people from all sides .
 The city was included on a quick political trip by President John F Kennedy in late 1963 .
 The Thirty-fifth President John Fitzgerald Kennedy was the first U.S. president born in the twentieth century . He was born in 1945 .
 He was born on May 29, 1917, in Brookline, Massachusetts, in an unpretentious middle-class suburb .
 He was the second oldest son of a family that began their American life with the immigration of Patrick Kennedy from Ireland in 1848 . The Kennedys were part of the liberal Eastern Establishment .
 At age forty-three, Kennedy became the nation’s youngest president . At the time of his death, he had lived a shorter life than that of any other president .
 His brief presidency—1,026 days—stirred the emotions of nearly every American . The president's brief presidency, 1,026-days, was one of the most divisive moments in American history .
 Perhaps due to his privileged background, he increasingly appeared more concerned with great historical issues such as civil rights, war, and peace than with parochial matters of business and politics .
 Jack, as the future president was called by his friends, attended only the best schools . The future president went to the best school in America .
 A bout with jaundice forced him to drop out of college, but upon recovery, he joined his older brother, Joseph Kennedy Jr., at Harvard . Kennedy Jr. is a Harvard graduate .
 Maintaining only a C average, Kennedy concentrated on sports, particularly football . Maintained only an average of C .
 Kennedy had bouts with illness compounded by a football injury that aggravated an already-weakened spinal column . Kennedy was a somewhat sickly child, with bouts of sickness compounded by football injury . Kennedy had a very thin spinal column and a very weak spinal cord .
 Kennedy left school during his junior year to travel in Europe . His father had been appointed United States ambassador to Great Britain after generous contributions to Franklin Roosevelt’s election campaign .
 Ambassador Kennedy was forced to resign because of his undisguised admiration for Germany’s Nazi regime . After war broke out, Ambassador Kennedy resigned over his admiration for the Nazis . Ambassador Kennedy had been forced to quit after the war .
 The best-selling book Why England Slept is written by the author of a thesis at Harvard . It was written in response to a thesis that was well received at Harvard and later rewritten .
 He began to show interest in a writing career but was interrupted by joining the United States Navy two months before the attack on Pearl Harbor .
 Early in the war, Kennedy served as an intelligence officer in Washington . He was transferred to the South Pacific after J Edgar Hoover told his father about young Kennedy’s love affair with a suspected Nazi agent .
 In the summer of 1943, Kennedy was in command of a Navy patrol boat, the PT-109 . Kennedy was a member of the Navy's World War II fleet .
 During a patrol in the Solomon Islands, the boat was struck and broken in half by a Japanese destroyer . The only such incident during the war was the only such an incident .
 He pulled his wounded chief engineer, Patrick McMahon, to a nearby island by swimming for four hours holding him on his back by gripping a strap of the man’s life jacket between his teeth . He pulled him to the island by holding the man's life jacket strap to his back
 Kennedy arranged for local natives to alert Navy officials to the group’s location in enemy-held territory and they soon were rescued . The group was rescued by the U.S. Navy .
 While recovering from his ordeal, Kennedy learned that his older brother, Joseph Jr., had been killed while flying a secret mission over Europe . Joseph Jr. Kennedy's brother was killed in a secret European mission .
 After the war, a reluctant Kennedy ran for and won a House seat from Massachusetts . Kennedy won a Senate seat in Massachusetts in 1964 .
 In later years, Joseph Kennedy was quoted as saying, “I told him Joe was dead and it was his responsibility to run for Congress.” Joseph Kennedy said he told him “Joe was dead. It was Joe’s responsibility”
 With the Kennedy name and Kennedy money behind him, Kennedy easily won two more elections to Congress . With the name and millions of dollars behind him he easily won more than two more .
 In 1952, he defeated Henry Cabot Lodge to become junior senator from Massachusetts . In 1952 he became junior senator . He was elected to the Massachusetts Senate in 1952 .
 By 1956, Kennedy's name was brought up as a possible running mate for Adlai Stevenson . Despite an uninspiring senatorial career, by 1956 Kennedy’s name had been brought up .
 Kennedy was edged out as vice presidential candidate by Estes Kefauver . Kennedy's graceful concession speech caused Kennedy's political stock to rise to new heights .
 Kennedy and his supporters went all out to ensure an impressive victory in his 1958 Senate reelection campaign in Massachusetts . With an eye toward the 1960 election, Kennedy went all-out to ensure a victory in the state .
 By 1960, Kennedy was ready for the Democratic presidential nomination, but there were hurdles to overcome . Kennedy was able to overcome the hurdles to become a presidential candidate .
 No Catholic president has ever been elected president . No Catholic has ever won a presidential election .
 He overcame this problem by entering —and winning—and winning —a series of state primary elections . He overcame it by entering and winning a series of primaries .

 At the 1960 Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, Kennedy was challenged only by conservative Texas senator Lyndon B Johnson .
 Kennedy knew that conservative Democrats needed to win against Richard Nixon . He forged temporary coalition by selecting defeated Johnson as his vice presidential running mate . Kennedy knew he needed a coalition of conservatives to defeat Nixon .
 His selection of Johnson shocked Kennedy supporters as well as Johnson’s supporters . Kennedy's selection of Kennedy's pick shocked Kennedy's supporters and Johnson's supporters .

 Mercer told authorities she was driving a rented white Valiant west on Elm Street just past the point where Kennedy was killed about two hours later . Mercer, then twenty-three years old, later told authorities that shortly before 11 m. the day of the assassination .
 She saw a young man get out of the passenger side of the truck, walk to a long tool compartment along the side, and remove a long paper bag . While waiting for the truck to move, she saw the young man remove the bag .
 The man then walked up on the Grassy Knoll carrying the package and was lost to her sight . The package was delivered to the woman's home in the early hours .
 She described this man as in his late twenties or early thirties, wearing a gray jacket, brown pants, a plaid shirt, and some sort of wool stocking cap with a tassel on it .
 Mercer said as she pulled alongside the truck, she locked eyes with the driver . Mercer described the driver as heavily built with a round face and light brown hair . Mercer said the driver is heavily built and has light brown skin .
 She said during this time, she saw three Dallas policemen standing by a motorcycle on the underpass talking . She said she also saw three officers standing by the motorcycle .

 Persons in the restaurant had informed authorities of her comments and presence at the assassination site, authorities say .

 One 8 mm home movie shows the front of the Depository just as Kennedy’s limousine passes the building turning onto Elm . The Depository was located at the intersection of Main and Houston, Texas .
 The film shows movement in both the corner window of the sixth floor and the window next to it . The film was shot in New York .

 In 1975, CBS television asked Itek Corporation to look again at the Hughes film . The Hughes film was released in 1975 .
 The company concluded that there were no moving images in the double window next to the sixth-floor corner window . The conclusion is still disputed by various photographic experts .
 In 1978, a second movie surfaced that supports the two-man allegation . But in late 1978, another movie surfaced supporting the two men .
 Charles L Bronson was standing just a few feet west of Hughes when he was killed . Bronson's film also shows the sixth-floor corner windows of the Depository just moments before the motorcade passed .
 Bronson’s film was viewed in 1963 by an FBI agent who reported that it “failed to show the building from which the shots were fired,” thus relegating the film to obscurity .
 The film was rediscovered in 1978 when it was mentioned in declassified FBI documents . It was discovered by the Dallas Morning News in 1978 after being mentioned in FBI files .
 Robert Groden, who served as staff consultant on photographic evidence for the House Select Committee on Assassinations, studied the film . The newspaper commissioned Groden to study the film. Groden served as a staff consultant for the committee .

 Also near the Stemmons Freeway sign were two of the most suspicious characters in Dealey Plaza .
 Despite their activities and the fact that both were captured in several photographs, this pair was never mentioned publicly until the House Select Committee on Assassinations investigation in the late 1970s .
 Two Suspicious Men stand near each other on the north sidewalk of Elm Street acting strangely . One began pumping a black umbrella while the other waved his right arm high in the air .
 Their activities were known only through analysis of assassination photographs . Their activities are known only by analysis of photographs .
 As Kennedy’s limousine began the gentle descent into Dealey Plaza, a man can be seen standing near the street-side edge of the Stemmons Freeway sign .
 He holds the umbrella in a normal fashion and the top of the umbrella almost reaches the bottom of the sign . He holds it in a regular fashion and holds it to his side .
 In photos taken minutes before Kennedy’s arrival, the umbrella is closed and, immediately after the shooting, pictures show the umbrella was closed again . The umbrella was later closed again after the incident .
 As seen in Zapruder film, the umbrella was pumped almost two feet into the air, twirled, and then lowered . Furthermore, as seen in the film, once Kennedy is exactly opposite the man with the umbrella, it was pumped two feet in the air .
 In photos, a man appears to be dark complected, perhaps black or Hispanic . At the same time, the second man raises his right hand into the air, possibly making a fist . The second man, possibly black or Latino, appears to make a fist in photos .
 This man was located on the outer edge of the Elm Street sidewalk opposite the umbrella man, who was on the inner edge . The umbrella man is located in the middle of the sidewalk, opposite the man on the sidewalk .
 The man with the open umbrella was the only person in Dealey Plaza with an open umbrella . The man was the last person in the area with a closed umbrella .
 Under the warm Texas sun, there was no reason to carry an open umbrella at that time . The incident occurred in the early hours of Saturday morning .
 Two prominent theories have emerged concerning the ‘umbrella man’ and his activities that day . The “umbrella’s’ activities have been the subject of numerous theories .
 The umbrella may have been a sophisticated weapon that fired a dart or “flechette” filled with a paralyzing agent, a researcher says .
 Cutler’s theory is supported by the 1975 testimony of a CIA weapons developer who told the Senate Intelligence Committee that just such an umbrella weapon was in the hands of the spy agency in 1963 . Cutler's theory supports his theory .
 Charles Senseney developed weaponry for the CIA at Fort Detrick, Maryland . He developed a dart-firing weapon he developed as looking like an umbrella . The weapon was developed by the CIA .
 The dart gun was silent in operation and fired through the webbing when the umbrella was open . He said the dart gun fired through webbing in the umbrella when it was closed .
 Senseney said the CIA had ordered about fifty such dart weapons and that they were operational in 1963 . The weapons were operational for the first time in 1963, he said .
 Cutler theorized that the umbrella was used to fire a paralyzing dart into Kennedy immobilizing him for marksmen with rifles . In his 1970 book, Cutler theorizes that the dart was fired into Kennedy .
 He claims this theory accounts for the small puncture wound in Kennedy’s throat described by Dallas doctors, but which was altered by the time of the Bethesda autopsy . He claims that the small hole in Kennedy's throat was found in his throat .
 According to Cutler, this dart explains Kennedy’s lack of motion during the shooting sequence . Cutler: ‘This dart explains why Kennedy was motionless during the sequence .
 Cutler’s theory cannot be summarily dismissed . Since such a weapon existed and since the actions of both Kennedy and the “umbrella man” were consistent with the operation of such a . weapon, Cutler's theory can't be dismissed .
 The use of such an exotic and questionably effective weapon in such a momentous event stretches credulity . However, the use of an exotic weapon is not without credibility .
 This theory suggests that Kennedy was killed by a crossfire coordinated by radiomen . This theory is based on a theory that the president was killed in a sniper attack on Kennedy .
 The two men were among the closest bystanders to the president when he was first struck . They gave signals indicating that he was not fatally hit and therefore more shots were required .
 The two men may have been providing Kennedy with a last-second sight of who was responsible for his death, researcher Gary Shaw said . Shaw said the two men could have been giving Kennedy with an eye on who killed him .
 Shaw recalled that throughout the planning of the Bay of Pigs Invasion, CIA officers had promised an “umbrella” of air protection of the Cuban invaders . Shaw recalls that during the planning, the CIA had promised to provide air protection to the invaders .
 Kennedy refused to authorize further U.S. military support for the invasion . This “umbrella” failed to materialize because Kennedy did not authorize further support .
 According to Shaw’s theory, the man with the open umbrella symbolized the promise of an air-support "umbrella" while the dark-complected man may have been one of the anti-Castro Cuban leaders known to Kennedy .
 Kennedy may have seen the open umbrella and the face of a Cuban he knew was involved in the Bay of Pigs . He may have realized who was participating in his death and realized who it was .
 The existence of the “umbrella man’s” and the darkcomplected man is fact, says author . “The existence of this man and the woman is fact. It is fact," he says .
 Two men sat down beside each other on the north sidewalk of Dealey Plaza . While virtually everyone was moved to action by the assassination, these two men sat next to each other .
 Dark-complected man appears to put a walkie-talkie to his mouth . The dark-competent man appeared to be in a dark mood .
 What seems to be an antenna can be seen jutting out from behind the man’s head while his right hand holds some object to his face . The image was taken by Jim Towner, who took the photograph .
 Several photos taken in the seconds following the assassination show both men sitting together on the Elm Street sidewalk .
 Moments later, the man with the umbrella gets up, takes one last look toward the motorcade still passing under the Triple Underpass, and begins walking east in the direction of the Depository . Moments later he gets up and heads east in direction of Texas State House .
 The dark-complected man saunters toward the Triple Underpass passing people rushing up the Grassy Knoll .
 He can be seen stuffing some object —the walkie-talkie?—into the back of his pants . He can't be heard stuffing something into his pants.
 Despite the suspicious actions of these two men, there is no evidence that the FBI or the Warren Commission made any effort to identify or locate them . The Warren Commission did not attempt to locate the two men .
 Researchers claim the lack of investigation of these men indicated the shallowness of the government probes into the assassination . Researchers claimed the lack to investigate the men indicated a shallownness of the investigation .
 Committee finally releases photograph of the ‘umbrella man’ to the news media . Committee urges anyone with knowledge of the man to come forward .
 The “umbrella man” suddenly was identified a few weeks after this national appeal . Coincidentally—if it was a coincidence—the ‘umbrella’ man’s identity was identified weeks later .
 In August 1978, an anonymous telephone caller told researcher Penn Jones Jr. that the man with the umbrella was a former Dallas insurance salesman named Louis Steven Witt . Witt was an insurance salesman, according to the caller . Witt is believed to be Witt, a former insurance salesman .
 Jones contacted some local newsmen, including this author, and together they confronted Witt . Witt was working as a warehouse manager when he was arrested . Jones contacted a local newsman and together, confronted Witt, who then worked for a warehouse .
 Witt was in Dealey Plaza on the day Kennedy was killed . Witt refused to talk with newsmen but acknowledged that he was there that day . Witt said he was in the Plaza at the time of Kennedy's death .
 His story was comic relief compared to the intense scrutiny of witnesses like Marina Oswald and Warren Commission critics . The Warren Commission has been criticized for questioning Oswald .
 Witt says he grabbed a large black umbrella and went to Dealey Plaza to heckle Kennedy . Witt told the committee that on the spur of the moment, he grabbed the umbrella . Witt said he grabbed an umbrella and then heckled Kennedy with a large umbrella .
 He claimed that someone had told him that an open umbrella would rile Kennedy . He claimed someone told him someone would be riled by Kennedy .
 The umbrella may have symbolized the appeasement policies of British Prime Minister Neville Chamberlain, who always carried an umbrella . The umbrella symbolized Chamberlain's policies, experts say .
 I think I went sort of maybe halfway up the grassy area [on the north side of Elm Street], somewhere in that vicinity . I think it was somewhere in the vicinity of the Elm Street .
 My view of the car during that length of time was blocked by the umbrella’s being open . The umbrella was open when the car was driven by the driver .
 Based on available photographs made that day, none of Witt’s statements were an accurate account of the actions of the “umbrella man” who stood waiting for the motorcade with his umbrella in the normal over-the-head position .
 There continues to be no official accounting for the dark-complected man who appears to have been talking on a radio moments after the assassination . And there is still no official explanation for the man who appeared to be talking on the radio .
 The House committee failed to identify or locate this man . Witt claimed he had no recollection of such a person, despite photographs that seem to show the ‘umbrella man’ talking with the dark man .
 No one has ever admitted the possibility of radios in use in Dealey Plaza . Witt asked Witt specifically if he recalled seeing the man with a walkie-talkie .
 Others in the crowd continued to give accounts that differed with the later government pronouncements . Meanwhile, others gave accounts that differ with the government .

 Forty-four-year-old James Altgens, a photographer for the Associated Press in Dallas, arrived in Dealey Plaza early .
 President Kennedy passed through downtown Dallas on his way to the White House . The photo was taken at the west end of Dealey Plaza . The president was passing through the downtown buildings .
 Altgens tried to station himself on the Triple Underpass, but was shooed away by a Dallas policeman . The officer told him it was railroad property and only railroad employees were allowed there .
 Altgens walked around by the Depository, then on to the intersection of Main and Houston, where he took a photo as the president passed . The president passed through the intersection .
 He then ran farther into the plaza, where he made several photographs from the south curb of Elm as the motorcade approached .
 On June 2, 1964, with the Warren Commission’s investigation winding down, Altgens was finally interviewed by FBI agents . The Warren Commission's investigation was winding down in 1964, and the FBI interviewed him .
 There was not another shot fired after the President was struck in the head . There was no further shot fired .
 That was the last shot—that much I will say with a great degree of certainty. That was last shot, that much I'm certain,’s a certainty. ‘I will say that much, I'm sure, that's the very last shot,' he says .
 Altgens was never called to testify to the Warren Commission . The Warren Commission was satisfied to merely cite from his FBI interrogation . Despite his vantage point and his photographic background, he never testified .
 Altgens’s photos were taken just seconds after the first shots were fired and showed a slender man standing in the doorway of the Depository . Another photo was taken seconds before the first shot was fired .
 Many people, including his mother, have claimed the man was Lee Harvey Oswald . Many people have claimed he was Oswald . The man's mother has also claimed he is Oswald .
 Near Altgens on the grassy triangle in the lower part of Dealey Plaza were all the closest witnesses to the actual assassination . The closest witnesses were a handful of people who witnessed the assassination .
 Charles Brehm, along with his five-year-old son, had watched the presidential motorcade turn onto Houston from near the front of the Depository building . The president's motorcade turns onto Houston, Texas, at the time .
 Brehm ran across Elm and stationed himself halfway between Houston and the Triple Underpass on the grassy triangle south of Elm . Brehm was holding his son when he ran across the street .
 I very definitely saw the effect of the second bullet that struck the President. I saw it very definitely, he said . The president was struck by a bullet that hit him, he added .
 That which appeared to be a portion of the President’s skull went flying slightly to the rear of the car and directly to its left . The President's car was hit by the accident .
 The skull landed in the grass not far from Brehm's location . Brehm said the piece of skull landed on the grass near him .
 Brehm, an ex-serviceman with experience in bolt-action rifles, was probably the closest witness to the fatal head shot . Brehm was a close friend of the suspect, who was killed by a single gunshot wound .
 He continued to tell his story over the years, even appearing at Dallas events concerning the assassination .
 Two significant home movies were made of the assassination . Maria Muchmore had moved from a position near Main and Houston to the center of the grassy triangle behind Brehm .
 She caught on film the final and fatal head shot to Kennedy and the disappearance of the limousine into the Triple Underpass .
 Orville Nix captured the entire assassination sequence on camera . Muchmore was shot by Muchmore's widow .
 Nix film most clearly shows the limousine coming to a halt with its brake lights on prior to the fatal head shot . It is the first time the limo has been shown to come to a brief halt with the lights on .
 Also in the Nix film are suspicious flashes of light on the Grassy Knoll, which is in the background . The film was released in November 2014 .
 Nix was interviewed by an assassination researcher some years later and asked about the direction of the shots . Nix said the shots were fired from a plane .
 Nix also said he later talked about the assassination with a friend, Forrest V Sorrels, then head of the Dallas Secret Service office . Nix said he also talked about it with the Secret Service chief, Forrest Sorrel .
 At the time of the assassination, Sorrels, too, believed shots had come from the picket fence on the Grassy Knoll, he said . He said at the time, he also believed shots came from the fence .
 The Warren Commission never called Nix to testify, although he indicated he was willing to do so to the FBI . Nix was never interviewed by the Commission, nor did the Commission have his film analyzed .
 In late 1966, Itek Corporation, which handles government contracts and is closely tied to the CIA, studied the film on the request of United Press International . The film was released by the CIA in 1966 .
 Scientists concluded that the gunman figure was actually shadows from a tree branch . Itek scientists concluded that it was actually a shadow of a tree .
 If the figure was merely shadows, it would seem that they should still be there in the later frames . The figure was just shadows, according to the film .
 Only a couple of the witnesses from the center grassy area testified to the Warren Commission . One of the best witnesses was never identified until years later when she was interviewed by an assassination researcher .
 A woman stood filming right behind Brehm and his son . Also taking films on the south side of Elm Street was a woman who stood filming on the street .
 Federal authorities were unable to identify or locate the “babushka lady’s” explosive story she had to tell . The Babushka Lady may be the reason authorities couldn’t find her .
 Beverly Oliver said she was 19 years old at the time of the assassination . She worked as a singer for the Colony Club, a strip-show club located next door to Jack Ruby’s Carousel Club .
 On November 22, she took a prototype Super-8 Yashica movie camera to Dealey Plaza . She ended up just behind Charles Brehm on the grassy triangle just south of Elm Street .
 The camera was a gift from a friend who had access to new camera technology . It was given to the family by a friend, who was gifted with new technology .
 Photos taken that day show Oliver filmed the assassination as the motorcade moved down Elm Street . Oliver was there at the time of the assassination .
 Oliver said she was approached by two men as she neared the Colony Club . Oliver said that on Monday following the assassination, two men approached her in the early hours .
 They said they knew she had taken film in Dealey Plaza and wanted to develop it for use as evidence . Police said they wanted to use the footage as evidence of her actions .
 Oliver identified Regis Kennedy as one of the men who took her film . Oliver identified him when shown photographs of FBI agents involved in the assassination . Oliver said he was a member of the FBI who took the film .
 Oliver married George McGann, a Dallas underworld character whose best man was Russell D Matthews . Not long after the assassination, Oliver married McGann .
 The committee also developed evidence connecting Matthews with associates of Florida Mafia chieftain Santos Trafficante .
 Matthews was a father figure to another Dallas thug, convicted murderer-for-hire Charles V Harrelson, the father of film star Woody Harrellson . Matthews was also a mentor to convicted murderer Charles V. Harrelsson, who was convicted of murder .
 Oliver revealed she and McGann had a two-hour conversation with Richard Nixon in a Miami hotel in 1968 . Oliver revealed that during the presidential campaign of 1968, McGann and Oliver had a conversation with Nixon .
 Watergate affair no longer seems so far-fetched after new information has been made public linking Nixon to organized crime figures . Why Nixon would meet with a well-known criminal is unclear .
 Oliver also said that two weeks prior to the Kennedy assassination, she was visiting in Ruby’s club . Oliver said she was in the club at the time of Kennedy's assassination .
 She recognized Oswald when his picture was broadcast following the assassination . She later recognized him when he was shown on television .
 A friend of Oliver's also knew of Oswald's being in Ruby’s club and spoke openly about it . Oswald was in the club at the time of the assassination .
 She remained quiet until the mid-1970s, when she was located and interviewed by Shaw and later by newsmen .
 Beverly Oliver was the object of a secret briefing by Commission attorney Robert Tannenbaum on March 17, 1977 . A transcript of this briefing was accidentally leaked to the news media . There is no mention of her or her film in the committee’s report .
 A report was not released to the public when it was prepared . Not to mention that when a report was prepared, it was not publicly released . The report was released without a release date .
 A concerted effort appeared to have been mounted to discredit her . Largely due to her hesitation in going public for so many years, she was reluctant to go public .
 Most accusations were based on flimsy arguments, such as one that claimed the shoes depicted on the person in the Dealey Plaza photographs appeared too small to fit the older and larger Oliver . Other than simply voicing disbelief, most accusations were unfounded .
 Neither Moorman nor Hill were there simply to see Kennedy . They were probably the closest witnesses to the fatal head shot other than Brehm .
 Both women had come to Dealey Plaza to take pictures of Dallas police motorcycle officers they fancied . Both women took pictures of officers they wanted to see .
 Hill had just moved to Dallas from Oklahoma and Moorman was showing her the city . He was trying to get her a date with one of the policemen who was escorting the motorcade .
 The women were stopped by a policeman at the corner of Elm and Houston . They were initially prevented from entering the grassy triangle in the center of the plaza .

 The Depository was a private company that acted as an agent for a number of book publishers, furnishing office space and providing warehousing, inventorying, and shipping .
 School systems would place orders with the publishers for textbooks and the publishers would send the orders along to the Depository . About a half dozen men acted as order fillers, collecting the books as per each order .
 Lee Harvey Oswald was an order filler for Oswald's assassin . Oswald's order fillers were ordered by the White House on November 22, 1963 . Oswald was killed in Dallas, Texas, in November 1963 .

 On the west side of Dealey Plaza is a large railroad bridge that spans the three main downtown Dallas traffic arteries of Commerce, Main, and Elm Streets . The Triple Underpass is located near the intersection of Commerce and Main .
 Since all three streets converge under this concrete bridge, it quickly became known as the Triple Underpass . Since all the three roads converge under the bridge, the triple underpass became known .
 To the east of the underpass is Dealey Plaza and downtown Dallas, while on the west there are several roads leading to freeway systems and an industrial area .
 Atop the east side of the Triple Underpass is a panoramic view of Dealey Plaza from a position about fifteen feet in the air . The view is a view from the east of the triple underpass .
 About a dozen men stood along the eastern edge of the underpass to watch the presidential motorcade pass beneath them on November 22, 1963 . This was the first time the motorcade had passed beneath them .
 Foster was one of two police officers assigned as security guards atop the Triple Underpass . Foster is one of the two officers assigned to guard atop the triple underpass in New Jersey . Foster was assigned as a security guard to guard the underpass .

 The bridge actually was railroad property and it was railway workers who walked over to the eastern banister to view the motorcade, he said . He did not believe they fell into the “unauthorized” category .

 In one clear frame, which depicts the presidential limousine just entering the Triple Underpass, a puff of smoke is clearly visible hanging in front of trees on the knoll .
 It has been well established that there was no other natural source of smoke in that area that day that day . It was well established there were no other sources of smoke that day.

 Warren Commission apologists for years have tried to argue that modern rifles do not smoke . Modern rifles smoke smoke, but modern rifles smoke, according to the commission .
 This is an error, since a recently oiled rifle or defective ammunition certainly can cause white smoke during firing . This is not the first time a rifle or ammunition can cause smoke .
 This was made clear to this author in the summer of 1978 when the House Select Committee on Assassinations fired rifles in Dealey Plaza in connection with their acoustical studies . The committee fired rifles at the site of the shooting .
 The idea that smoke drifted over Elm Street from the knoll is highly plausible . And considering the slightly gusting breeze from the north that day that day, it's highly likely .
 It is now obvious that many people that day saw this puff of smoke drifting down from the knoll . Witnesses said they smelled gunpowder in the lower end of Dealey Plaza .
 The authorities, particularly the FBI and the Warren Commission, did not want to hear about it . However, it is equally obvious that the authorities, including the Warren commission, did want it to be heard about .

 Jim Tague was the third man wounded in Dealey Plaza on November 22, 1963 . He singlehandedly caused more concern than anyone else in the 1963-1964 federal investigation .
 The Third Wounded Man James Thomas Tague, like Jean Hill and Mary Moorman, was not planning to see Kennedy . Tague was not going to attend Kennedy's memorial service at the time .
 Shortly after noon that day, he had driven downtown to take a girlfriend to lunch . He had driven to take her out for a lunch .
 Tague was stopped in traffic that was halted at Houston Street due to arrival of the presidential motorcade . The motorcade was the first of its kind to arrive in Washington, DC .
 The hood of his car was just poking out of the east side of the Triple Underpass . The hood was poking out the east of the triple underpass .
 Tague stood by the underpass on a small concrete median separating Commerce and Main to watch the motorcade . Tague got out of his car and stood by a concrete median on the side of the road .
 He ducked behind the corner of the underpass after hearing more shots . However, he realized what was happening and ducked to the corner .

 There was no mention of the incident in the news accounts at the time nor was there any investigation of the bullet mark on the curb until the summer of 1964 . The bullet mark was found on a curb in 1964 .
 It was widely reported that the first shot struck Kennedy in the back, the second bullet hit Governor Connally, and the third was the fatal head shot . During late 1963 and early 1964, it was widely thought Kennedy was hit in back .
 Tague’s story of yet another bullet was totally inconsistent with the loneassassin/three-shot theory being formulated by the Warren Commission, which initially seemed prepared to ignore both Tague and the bullet mark on the curb .
 In late May 1964, about a month before the Warren Commission finally talked to Tague, the car salesman took a camera to Dealey Plaza to photograph the mark on the curb . Tague was a car salesman who sold the car .

 FBI document attempted to explain the disappearance of a mark that had been clearly seen eight months earlier . FBI document attempts to explain disappearance of mark that was visible eight months ago .
 It should be noted that, since this mark was observed on November 22, 1963, there have been numerous rains, which could have possibly washed away such a mark . The area is cleaned by a street cleaning machine about once a week .
 A Dallas policeman and a sheriff’s deputy had mentioned Tague in their reports, although not by name . Assistant United States Attorney Stroud's letter said Tague's story could no longer be ignored .

 Following Tague’s testimony, the Commission again asked the bureau to investigate the matter .
 FBI found the mark, removed the piece of curb in question and took it to Washington for analysis . This time the FBI removed it from the curb and sent it to the U.S. for analysis.
 Small foreign metal smears were found adhering to the curbing section within the area of the mark . The incident occurred at the site of the incident .
 Metal smears were spectrographically determined to be essentially lead with a trace of antimony . These metal smears are essentially lead and antimony, and were found to contain antimony and lead .
 Damage to curbing would have been much more extensive if a rifle bullet had struck the curbing without first having struck some other object . Further, the damage to the curb was much more severe if a bullet had hit the curb without first striking another object .
 This mark could not have been made by the first impact of a high-velocity bullet . Therefore, it could not be made by a high velocity bullet .
 FBI now says mark had to have been made by a rifle bullet but not on first impact . FBI had initially said no bullet hit the curb, but now said it was made by rifle bullet . FBI says bullet had to hit curb but not first impact on impact .
 If the FBI is correct, the mark on the curb could only have been made by the lead fragment of a bullet . The FBI has a history of misinformation and omission by the bureau regarding assassination evidence .
 The only one that could have lost such an amount of lead is the final head shot and that was at a location more than two hundred feet away, a considerable distance for a small fragment to travel and still impact the curb as described .
 Another possibility was that the mark was made by a lead bullet without copper jacketing . Another possibility, never considered by the Warren Commission, was that a bullet without jacketing made the mark .
 Oswald allegedly used a different rifle from the one allegedly used by Oswald . But of course, this would indicate different ammunition and perhaps a different weapon .
 The curb was hit by a large fragment of bullet that had already struck the street . Or perhaps the fragment had already hit the street and had separated from the copper jacket . Witnesses saw one of the witnesses who saw one do just that .
 The Warren Commission was compelled to construct a scenario of the assassination that included the “single-bullet theory,” which postulates that one bullet caused seven wounds to Kennedy and Connally . Whatever the truth of the curb bullet and despite the attempt to ignore this evidence, the
 The Grassy Knoll is a small northern portion of Dealey Plaza known as the Grassy knoll . The area has been the subject of controversy for decades .
 There are two grassy knolls on both the north and south sides of the west end of the plaza . During the assassination of President John F Kennedy, it was the north knoll that drew public attention .
 Running along the top of the knoll was a wooden picket fence about five feet high . The knoll is a knoll with a five-foot-high fence .
 In front of this fence were shrubs and evergreen trees that, even in late November, provided a leafy canopy over the fence . The fence is surrounded by shrubs, trees and shrubbery .
 The fence ran east approximately seventy-five feet from the north edge of the Triple Underpass . It turned north for about fifty feet, ending in a parking area behind a concrete pergola located to the west of the Depository .
 Abraham Zapruder film was made from a vantage point atop a low concrete wall on the south end of this pergola . The most famous home movie of all time was made in this place . It was from the vantage point of the low-level concrete wall .
 The Zapruder Film is a 26.6-second, 8 mm film made on November 22, 1963 . It became the cornerstone of investigations, both public and private, in the years after the Kennedy assassination .
 It has been long regarded as the most objective, and thus most important, piece of evidence in the attempts to unravel what actually happened to President Kennedy . President Kennedy was assassinated in 1963 .
 His secretary, Lillian Rogers, urged him to make use of his new camera . It was a Bell & Howell 8mm camera with a telephoto lens with a Bell and Howell 8 mm lens .
 Zapruder made a fourteen-mile round-trip drive to his home to pick up his camera . He had to drive 14 miles round trip to get his camera back to his father's home .
 By the time he returned, crowds were already gathering to watch the motorcade . The motorcade was already underway when he returned from the hospital .
 After trying several different locations, Zapruder climbed onto a four-foot-high concrete block at the end of two steps leading to the pergola on the north Grassy Knoll .
 He almost lost his balance while testing his camera on some nearby office workers . He asked one in the group, his receptionist Marilyn Sitzman, to join him and provide steady support . He nearly lost balance while trying to test his camera with a group of workers .
 From this excellent vantage point, Zapruder and Sitzman watched the motorcade approach Elm Street . From this vantage point they were able to watch the motorcadence . Zapruders and others watched the parade .
 Zapruder set the camera’s speed control on “run” and his lens on ‘telephoto’ He then proceeded to film the entire assassination sequence .
 The film must be seen run in its entirety for a viewer to receive its maximum impact . The film has been released in cinemas since 2008 .
 The motorcade curves onto Elm and begins moving slowly toward the camera . It is the first time the motorcade has left the scene of a car crash .
 President Kennedy and his wife are smiling and waving to opposite sides of the street . President Kennedy's wife and President Kennedy were waving to each other on the same side .
 Kennedy's limousine disappears for a brief second behind a freeway sign . When it emerges, Kennedy is already reacting to a shot . Kennedy was reacting to the shot .
 He does not appear to say anything, but only remains stiff and upright, sagging slightly to the left . He appears to be leaning slightly to his left .
 Connally turns to his right, apparently trying to see behind him, then begins to turn back to his left when he freezes . Connally freezes when he tries to look behind him .
 Kennedy meanwhile has placed her hand on her husband’s arm and is looking at him horrified as he continues to sag toward her . Kennedy meanwhile, meanwhile, is holding her husband's arm around her .
 After an almost imperceptible forward motion of his head, the entire right side of his skull explodes in a halo of blood and brain matter . Suddenly, after an almost . imperceptable forward motion, his head suddenly explodes .
 Kennedy is slammed violently backward to the left rear where he rebounds off the back of the seat and falls toward the car’s floor . Kennedy was slammed to the rear of the car and fell to the floor .
 Kennedy climbs onto the trunk of the limousine in an effort to grab something . Secret Service agent leaps onto the rear of the car, which finally begins to accelerate . Kennedy climbs on to the trunk, while Secret Service agents jump on the rear .
 The Commission placed the moment of the first shot at the point where Kennedy was out of Zapruder’s sight behind the sign . The Commission moved the shot closer to the visual effect of a strike on Connally, buttressing the “single bullet theory”
 The Commission abolished the problem of how an assassin in the sixth-floor window could have accurately fired through obscuring tree branches . By moving the time of the shot forward, the Commission also abolished the wotrisome problem .

 No one who has viewed the Zapruder film has been unaffected by the final, gory head shot followed instantaneously by Kennedy’s violent fall rearward .
 When published by the Warren Commission, the critical frames that depict the rearward motion of Kennedy’s head were transposed to indicate a forward motion . The Warren Commission published the images of Kennedy's head .

 The American public finally got the chance to view the Zapruder film only because of the Clay Shaw trial in New Orleans during 1967-1969 . The Clay Shaw case was the only reason for the public to see the film .
 During that turbulent trial, New Orleans district attorney Jim Garrison tried to prove there was a conspiracy to kill President Kennedy . New Orleans Trade Mart director Clay Shaw was a member of that conspiracy .
 Garrison subpoenaed the Zapruder film from Time-Life Corp. He subpoenaed it as part of an attempt to prove the existence of a conspiracy . Garrison said the film would prove that the government was involved in conspiracy .
 Time-Life fought this subpoena all the way to the Supreme Court . The Supreme Court ruled that the corporation had to comply with the legal subpoena .
 Time-Life grudgingly turned over to Garrison a somewhat blurry copy of the film . Garrison was able to get a blurry copy, but that was enough for him .
 In March 1975, a copy of the film was aired nationally about midnight on ABC's Goodnight America thanks to guests Robert Groden and comedian Dick Gregory .
 At long last, the American public was able to see for themselves the assassination of the thirty-fifth president . The assassination of George W. Bush was finally revealed .
 Within a few years clearer copies of the Zapruder film became available to the public . The film was released in 1945 .
 In 1971, author David Lifton was permitted to view an exceptionally good-quality copy of the Zapruder film in Time-Life’s Los Angeles office .
 His suspicion that the film may have been tampered with by persons with access to sophisticated photographic equipment was heightened in 1976 with the release of CIA Item 450 . The film was released by the CIA in 1976 .
 Documents tell of the existence of either a negative or master positive of the film . One of the documents tells of the production of four prints, one “test print” and three duplicates .
 One original and three copies of the original prints were found in Dallas the day after the assassination . That number of prints is exactly what existed in Dallas that day after .

 The suppression, alteration, and deception surrounding the Zapruder film may eventually reveal more than the film itself . And like so much else in the assassination case, the suppression and alteration surrounding the film may reveal more .

 Virgil Edward Hoffman was twenty-six years old on November 22, 1963 . Hoffman was driving toward downtown Dallas on the Stemmons Freeway when he noticed numerous people lining the freeway . Hoffman died at age of 26 in Dallas .
 He suddenly realized that President Kennedy was to motorcade through the city that day . He stopped his car just north of a railroad bridge across Stemmons and joined the spectators .
 Only someone who was there that day could have known that many people were lining Stemmons to get a glimpse of the president's motorcade .
 After waiting for a time, Hoffman decided to walk along the shoulder of the freeway to a point where it crossed over Elm Street in hopes of getting a view into Dealey Plaza . Hoffman walked along the highway to get a view of the Plaza .
 Being unable to hear, he was not aware that Kennedy’s motorcade was passing through the plaza . The motorcade passes through the area .
 He said he was aware of movement on the north side of the picket fence . However, he said he did not know of movement in the area .
 He became aware of a man running west along the back side of the fence . The man was wearing a dark suit and a tie .
 The man reached a metal-pipe railing at the west end of the fence . He tossed the rifle to a second man standing on the west side of the pipe near the railroad tracks .
 The second man was wearing light coveralls and a railroad worker’s hat . Both men were wearing railroad coveralls .
 The man disassembled the rifle, placed it in a soft brown bag, then walked nonchalantly north into the rail yards in the general direction of the railroad tower containing Lee Bowers .
 The man in the suit, meanwhile, had turned and run back along the picket fence until midway, when he stopped and began walking calmly toward the corner of the fence .
 Hoffman could not see the corner due to cars and over-hanging tree branches . Hoffman said he was not sure if he would be able to get to the corner .
 Unable to hear, Hoffman was at a loss to understand what was happening as he watched these men . Hoffman was unable to hear what he was trying to understand .

 Hoffman stopped and threw up his hands and could only watch helplessly as the motorcade rushed past him onto Stemmons in the mad rush to Parkland Hospital . Hoffman stopped throwing his hands as he watched helplessly .

 Francis Gary Powers and his ill-fated U-2 spy plane were brought down six months after a former Marine named Lee Harvey Oswald arrived in Moscow and told an American embassy official he planned to give the Soviets classified information .
 Oswald went so far as to state that he knew something that would be of “special interest” to Soviet intelligence, a CIA operative recalled . Oswald went even further in saying that he was aware of something that was of "special interest" to the Soviet intelligence .
 The Russians had known about the U-2 program for some time . Their antiaircraft missiles were capable of shooting down the high-flying craft . The Russians knew about the program and were able to shoot them down .
 The Soviets lacked detailed altitude information on the U-2 that would have allowed them to accurately control their missiles at great altitudes . What the Soviets lacked was detailed altitude data on the aircraft .

 In a 1952 military coup, former Cuban army sergeant Fulgencio Batista seized control of Cuba . Cuba had been under U.S. trusteeship since 1898 .
 A dictator and a despot, Batista nevertheless was supported by the United States . Batista worked closely with many American groups, especially organized criminals .
 By the late 1950s, Cuba was a mecca for American gamblers, tourists, investors, and offshore banking speculators . Cuba was the center of Cuba's gambling and tourists .
 Only one man seemed determined to overthrow Batista— a young attorney named Fidel Castro . Fidel Castro was a young lawyer who was determined to topple Batista . Castro was one of the few men in Cuba to take over the Batista government .
 Fidel Castro born the son of a Spanish-born plantation owner on August 13, 1926 . Fidel Alejandro Castro Ruz had an active boyhood in rural eastern Cuba . Fidel Castro was born in 1926 .
 He once threatened to burn the house down if his parents didn’t send him to school, he said . He also threatened to set fire to the house if he wasn't sent to school .
 In 1952, he ran for Parliament but was stymied when the dictator Batista canceled the elections . He ran for a seat in Parliament in 1952, but was canceled by Batista .
 Castro made his first assault on Batista on July 26, 1953, attacking the dictator’s Moncada Barracks . Castro made the assault on the dictator in 1953 .
 Castro was released after twenty-two months in prison . Castro was sentenced to fifteen years in prison for his role in Castro's murder . Castro served two years of a 15-year prison sentence .
 He fled to Mexico, where he began reorganizing his guerrilla fighters . He then fled to the country to join guerrilla fighters in Mexico .
 He used the brutality displayed by Batista at the Moncada Barracks as a rallying point . He named his revolution the “26th of July Movement” after the disastrous attack .
 In 1956, Castro swam the Rio Grande and entered the United States to arrange the purchase of a dilapidated yacht named the Granma . Castro was in the U.S. to arrange to buy the yacht .
 The Mexican revolutionary returned to Mexico and began planning the invasion of his homeland . He planned to invade Mexico's homeland .
 Castro even made his invasion plans public . Confident that he would rapidly gain followers, Castro made it public . Castro made the invasion public .
 On December 2, 1956, when he and eighty-two guerrillas waded ashore on the swampy coast of his native Oriente Province, Batista’s soldiers were waiting in ambush .
 Only twelve guerrillas, including Castro, survived and escaped into the Sierra Maestra mountains . Castro was the only survivor of the guerillas .
 Castro grew his now-famous beard during the years he spent in the mountains . Castro and his followers began to take the initiative after several years of basic survival . Castro's followers took the initiative .

 Castro closed down gambling casinos and houses of prostitution that had been the source of an estimated $100 million a year for organized crime in the U.S. The casinos were source of $100million a year .
 By 1960 he had seized more than $700 million in U.S. property, including banks that had been accused of laundering money for American interests . He had nationalized Cuba's sugar industry in 1960 .
 Within a few years, illiteracy had been reduced from 24 percent to 4 percent . The country's illiteracy rate was reduced to 24 percent in a decade .
 Castro also proclaimed that he was the leader of the socialist revolution in South America . But he strongly maintained that he wasn't a communist .

 As Castro’s social, economic, and agricultural reforms continued, often with brutal effectiveness, Cubans began to split into two factions . The Fidelistas and the anti-Castroites, many of whom fled Cuba . Many of those who fled Cuba fled the country .
 By the end of the first year of Castro’s takeover, more than 100,000 Cubans were living in the U.S. More than a million Cubans now live in the United States .
 As the U.S. stepped up its program of isolating Cuba, Fidel Castro grew more and more fearful of an armed invasion by the United States . Castro's government cut off the island’s sugar markets and oil supplies, then introduced arms and saboteurs into Cuba .
 On January 3, 1961, the United States ended diplomatic relations with Cuba . Castro demanded the U.S. embassy staff be cut to only eleven persons . The United States cut diplomatic ties with Cuba in 1961 after Castro demanded that only 11 persons be employed .

 Immigrants to the United States in the late 1800s and early 1900s found themselves crammed into inner-city ghettos spawning a multitude of street gangs . Immigrants found themselves trapped by their inability to speak English, lack of education, and class and cultural differences .
 They carried names like the Whyos, the Dead Rabbits, the Bowery Boys, the Tenth Avenue Gang, the Gas House Gang, and the Midnight Terrors . They were known as the Bowersy Boys and the Tenth Ave Gang .
 Young toughs would rob and beat their victims in broad daylight, with little to fear from the police . As long as they confined their illegal activities to the ghetto and its cowed population, the police would not be able to stop them .
 In the various ethnic communities some people had belonged to the Mafia of Sicily, the Camorra of Italy, and the Tongs of China . In the other countries some people belonged to secret societies such as the Mafia .
 They brought the learned terror and intimidation of these societies to their new home, where it found fertile soil . The learned terror was brought to these societies, and they brought it to their home .
 City gangs were becoming more adept at their profession and expanding operations to include gambling, prostitution, and lotteries . As America entered the twentieth century, the city gangs were expanding operations .
 They also were the bankers for the poor, charging exorbitant interest rates from those who could borrow money nowhere else . They also charged exorbitantly interest rates for those who were able to borrow money .
 Irish gangs gained advantage by allying themselves with political figures . Unhampered by a language barrier and experienced in politics in their homeland, the gangs gained advantages by allaying themselves with politicians .
 As gang leaders grew more wealthy, politicians came seeking favors, politicians sought favors . But as the gang leaders became more powerful, politicians began seeking favors from them .
 American groups such as the Women’s Christian Temperance Union and the Anti-Saloon League lobbied Congress and state legislatures to prohibit the manufacture and sale of distilled spirits .
 With many male voters off serving in the military and with the emotional exhaustion and moral primness following World War I, their dream became reality . Finally, with many men off serving, the idea was realized .
 In December 1917, Congress passed the Eighteenth Amendment to the Constitution, prohibiting the sale of intoxicating beverages . By January 1919, the necessary thirty-six of the forty-eight states had ratified the amendment .
 In October 1919, Congress passed the Volstead Act, which created the government bureaucracy needed to enforce the Eighteenth Amendment . President Woodrow Wilson vetoed the act overriding the veto of President Wilson's veto of the act .

 Since the first conflicts of man, there has been a need for intelligence, or information on the activities and purposes of a perceived enemy . Agents have been involved in the creation of the U.S. since the first wars .
 In modern America the growth of myriad intelligence organizations over the years has spawned an intelligence industry . The growth of the intelligence industry has spawned a huge intelligence industry.
 Under acronyms such as CIA, DIA, NSA, ONI, NRO, AFOSI, DEA, and NGA, these intelligence power bases have grown far beyond their original charters .
 Many are concerned that these disparate agencies, with the exception of the military, are now bundled together within the Department of Homeland Security . The military is the only exception .
 The Central Intelligence Agency is a government organization that does much more than merely collect and interpret intelligence . The agency's history reveals that it does more than just collect intelligence . It's a government agency that does not only collect intelligence but also interpret it .
 In less than ten years after its creation in 1947, this coordinating agency grew to oversee military operations, destabilization efforts in foreign countries, and assassination of national leaders . The agency was aided by an unholy alliance with organized crime .
 At the end of World War II, information on a wide variety of issues and activities was being handled by as many as a dozen intelligence organizations, including those within the military .
 President Harry S Truman and others perceived a need for a coordinating intelligence unit . Truman saw the need for an intelligence unit in order to protect the nation's interests .
 Congressional Joint Committee on the Pearl Harbor Attack concluded that the fragmentation of U.S. intelligence prior to 1941 resulted in the Japanese taking this nation by surprise . This need was further reinforced by the need for intelligence in the United States .
 None of the existing intelligence units wanted to relinquish power or authority . None of these intelligence units would relinquish their authority, officials say .
 During World War II, the Office of Strategic Services proved most effective against the Axis powers . It was headed by General William “Wild Bill” Donovan . Donovan was one of the most colorful in the war .
 The OSS gathered a remarkable amount of information on the enemy, but also engaged in various covert activities . OSS was a major intelligence agency in the U.S.
 The operation provided the factual background for many a fictional spy novel and movie . It was a rough-and-tumble wartime operation that provided the historical background .
 The OSS was closed down at the end of the war, and on January 22, 1946, President Truman signed a directive creating the National Intelligence Authority .
 The operating arm of the NIA was the Central Intelligence Group, made up of veteran intelligence officers from the participating departments .
 Truman specifically prohibited any clandestine or paramilitary activities . To limit the CIG, Truman specifically banned any clandestine activities .
 The men of action soon wanted more elbow room in their restricted world of intelligence gathering . And they soon wanted it more .
 By 1947, the CIG’s staff had grown to nearly 2,000, with about one-third operating overseas . About a third of CIG's staff was overseas .
 Truman signed the National Security Act on September 15, 1947, creating the Air Force as a separate branch of the services . The War Department was renamed the Department of Defense in 1947 .
 With little notice, this act created the Central Intelligence Agency . It was the U.S. first full-blown peacetime intelligence service .

 The CIA was responsible only to the National Security Council, headed by the president . The act effectively gave the president absolute control over the new agency . The National Security Act was passed in the heat of the growing anti-communist hysteria .
 The CIA had its own budget, much of this off the books and handled through the little-known Exchange Stabilization Fund of the Treasury Department . The CIA was authorized to hire and train its own personnel .
 No clandestine or paramilitary operations and no internal spying are allowed in the old CIG . Yet the same restrictions remain, including no clandestine operations and internal spying .
 The CIA in 1948 became active in suppressing communist influence in the national elections in Italy . The National Security Council approved the use of the phrase .
 This marked the beginning of the agency’s career of meddling in the affairs of other nations . The agency has been known to meddle in the world's affairs .
 In 1949, the Central Intelligence Act was passed, exempting the CIA from all laws requiring the disclosure of “functions, names, official titles, salaries and number of personnel employed by the Agency” and allowing the director to spend money from its secret budget simply by signing vouchers
 The CIA began to flex its muscles after being given secret funds . Now operating with secret funds and with the vague authority of “other such functions and duties related to intelligence,” the CIA .

 This vague phrase has provided the CIA with freedom to engage in covert action, the right to intervene secretly in the internal affairs of other nations, the CIA says . The CIA has since been able to engage covert action in secret .
 It has done so usually with the express approval of the White House, but almost always without the consent of Congress, and virtually never with the knowledge of the American people . The White House has often done so without the approval of Congress and without the permission of the public .
 In 1948, the Office of Policy Coordination was created by the National Security Council as a covert psychological and paramilitary operations unit under Frank Wisner . The Office was created as part of the CIA's covert operations operations .
 By 1951, the OPC had run afoul of so many U.S. laws and policies it was merged into the CIA . The OPC was known thereafter as the CIA’s Department of Plans .
 Allen Dulles was appointed as the new director of the CIA . Dulles' appointment was thwarted by the appointment of Dulles as the director .
 By 1955, the CIA contained more than 15,000 employees, not including thousands of foreign assets and contract agents . The CIA was the largest intelligence agency in the world at the time .
 The CIA created a number of wholly or partly owned properties, or “fronts,” to provide cover for clandestine operations . The CIA's secret budget is often disguised as portions of other United States government budgets .
 These fronts included airlines, import-export companies, “high-tech” firms, advertising agencies, foundations, and many others .

 This law became known as the Mann Act after its sponsor, representative James Robert Mann of Illinois . The Mann Act became known after it was sponsored by Representative Mann in Illinois .

 On the day of his inauguration, Thomas Jefferson walked from the boardinghouse where he was staying to the Capitol without benefit of any protection . Jefferson was the first president to be inaugurated without protection .
 It was symptomatic of the young Republic that presidents had not yet acquired the mantle of royalty and thus did not require protection . President George W. Bush was assassinated at the age of 16 in 1877 .
 This naiveté began to change after the assassination attempt on president Andrew Jackson on January 10, 1835 . Andrew Jackson's assassination attempt was an assassination attempt in 1835.
 In August 1842, a drunken painter threw rocks at President John Tyler, who was walking on the White House grounds . The incident occurred during a drunken incident involving a drunken painting .
 Congress soon passed an act creating an auxiliary watch of the Washington Metropolitan Police for the protection of public and private property . The captain and fifteen men were part of the auxiliary watch .
 The act was aimed primarily at protecting property, particularly the White House . It was the crude beginning of presidential protection .
 Abraham Lincoln was fatally shot by actor John Wilkes Booth in Ford’s Theater on April 14, 1865 . There was no clamor to create official protection for the president . Even after the president was shot, no official protection was created .
 The Secret Service was organized as a division of the Treasury Department the year Lincoln was killed . It originally was meant only to pursue counterfeiters . Lincoln was assassinated in 1862 .
 It was not until after the assassination of president James A Garfield in 1881 that a serious attempt was made to protect presidents . It was only until after Garfield's assassination that serious attempts were made .
 The number of White House policemen grew to twenty-seven after mail threats increased against Grover Cleveland . It was not until 1894 that Secret Service agents were informally assigned to the president .
 Throughout the Spanish-American War, a small detail of Secret Service men were stationed at the White House . The Secret Service was a small part of the Secret Service .
 President McKinley was assassinated on September 6, 1901 . Secret Service protection of president William McKinley did not prevent his assassination .
 The McKinley assassination provoked a response from Congress . Congress ordered the Secret Service to assume full-time protection of the president . McKinley's assassination prompted a response to Congress .
 By World War II, the White House detail of the Secret Service had grown to thirty-seven men . The Secret Service was once at the center of the world's largest Secret Service .
 Legislation was passed permanently authorizing the Secret Service to protect not only the president, but also his immediate family, the president-elect, and the vice president . The legislation was passed in 1951 .
 By 1963, the Secret Service remained a small and specialized group restricted by law . The Secret Service was still a small, specialized group .
 The Secret Service had an average strength of more than five hundred and ran sixty-five field offices throughout the country . Nevertheless, the Secret Service was at the peak of its peak of five hundred .

 The Secret Service and the Kennedy people decided the Women’s Building would be a preferable location . It presented fewer security problems and could accommodate more people, the Secret Service said .

 Kennedy's Secret Service agents were drinking well into the morning hours of November 22 at a notorious Fort Worth club, the Cellar .
 Chief James J Rowley obtained statements from the ten agents involved, plus some Fort Worth news reporters and Pat Kirkwood, the club’s owner and an acquaintance of Jack Ruby .
 Everyone, including Kirkwood, stressed that the Cellar had no license to sell alcoholic drinks . Kirkwood: Cellar was not licensed to sell alcohol .
 Employees are strictly enjoined to refrain from the use of intoxicating liquor during the hours they are officially employed at their post of duty, or when they may reasonably expect that they may be called upon to perform an official duty .
 All members of the White House Detail and Special Agents cooperating with them on Presidential and similar protective assignments are considered to be subject to call for official duty while in travel status .
 Use of intoxicating liquor of any kind, including beer and wine, by members of the White House Detail . While they are in travel status, is prohibited, the use of alcohol is prohibited .

 Chief Rowley testified that under ordinary circumstances he would have taken disciplinary action against those agents who had been drinking in clear violation of the regulation . Rowley said he would not have taken action against agents who were drinking .
 He felt disciplinary action might have given rise to an inference that the violation of the regulation had contributed to the tragic events of November 22 . However, he felt that any disciplinary action would have been inappropriate .

 President Kennedy was president of the United States in the 1960s . He faced racial unrest, but it was not his only domestic problem . Kennedy was assassinated in 1968 .
 He was being verbally attacked not only by poor minorities with rising expectations, but also by wealthy businessmen who felt threatened by his announced social reforms .
 Big business was already leery of Kennedy, who as a senator had opposed the Taft-Hartley law, aimed at curbing the power of labor unions . As president, Kennedy had failed to consult the business world before making certain appointments .
 Kennedy used the power of the presidency to force U.S. steel manufacturers to roll back recent price increases . The fears of big business increased in the spring of 1962 when Kennedy used his power to force United States steel companies to reverse recent price hikes .
 Kennedy already had served notice on the giant steel companies in September 1961 . Kennedy sent a letter to industry leaders warning them against any price increases .
 The steel industry, in short, can look forward to good profits without an increase in prices . Steel industry is looking forward to profitable profits without a price hike .
 On April 6, 1962, at the request of the federal government, the Steelworkers Union agreed to limit its wage demands to a tencent hourly increase beginning that summer . The union agreed to an hourly wage increase of ten cents .
 On April 11, United States Steel and five other major steel companies announced a 3. percent hike in the cost of steel . U.S. Steel announced the hike on April 11 .
 The Defense Department awarded a $5 million contract to a smaller steel firm that had not raised prices . Administration officials suggested an FBI investigation .
 The next day, the six major firms announced their price increase had been rescinded . Six major firms said their price increases were rescinded the next day .
 Kennedy’s denunciation of the steel executives sent shock waves through the business community . Kennedy: ‘I’m not going to back the steel industry. I’ve got a lot of respect for the people of steel workers,’ he said .
 He had demonstrated that a proactive president could influence major corporate decisions . President Obama has demonstrated that he can influence major decisions .

 During 1963, the Justice Department’s Antitrust Division won forty-five of forty-six cases . General Dynamics ordered General Dynamics to drop a division dealing with industrial gases .
 Business and political leaders began to regret that the winner of the 1960 presidential election had not been Richard M Nixon . Richard M. Nixon won the White House in 1960 .
 Richard Milhous Nixon was the only U.S. president to resign under the threat of certain impeachment . Nixon resigned from office under threat of being impeached . Nixon and JFK were assassinated in 1968 .
 Few know of or recall Nixon’s connection with the Kennedy assassination . Nixon was in Dallas the day Kennedy died but couldn’t recall that fact when interviewed by the FBI .
 Born January 9, 1913, in Yorba Linda, California, Nixon was a self-made man . He reached the pinnacles of power after struggling up from a background of meager financial circumstances .
 Nixon wanted to attend Harvard like young Kennedy, but was forced to settle for California’s Whittier College . He honed his skills as a debater . Nixon wanted Harvard, but settled for California college .
 Shortly after Pearl Harbor, Nixon took a job with the tire-rationing department of the Office of Price Administration in Washington, D.C.
 Charles "Bebe" Rebozo began his profitable career selling recapped tires . Nixon’s lifelong friend Charles “Bebe” began his successful career selling tires . Bebe was Nixon's lifelong friend .
 Later in the war, Nixon enlisted in the Navy and served in the South Pacific . On one island he built a small shack used for high-stakes gambling and drinking .
 Nixon was named to the House UnAmerican Activities Committee . His name became nationally known due to his part in the case of Alger Hiss, a government official accused of being a Soviet spy .
 His opponent was Helen Douglas, a liberal former Hollywood actress named Helen Douglas .
 The man most responsible for Nixon’s smear tactics was his close friend and campaign manager Murray Chotiner, a lawyer who represented ranking mobsters . He had connections to reputed New Orleans Mafia chief Carlos Marcello and Teamsters leader Jimmy Hoffa .
 Throughout the Eisenhower years, the war-hero president snubbed Nixon both politically and socially . Nixon was a major ally of the war hero during the Eisenhower administration .
 Nixon was busy building up his own power base with men of dubious backgrounds . He was busy in the early days of Watergate . But he was also building up a power base in Washington .
 Mobster Mickey Cohen gave Chotiner $5,000 for Nixon's 1946 congressional campaign . Cohen raised $75,000 from Las Vegas gamblers for Nixon’s 1950 Senate race .
 Marcello had a suitcase filled with $500,000 cash which was going to Nixon . The suitcase was filled with money which went into Nixon's coffers .
 Nixon’s organized-crime contacts apparently continued even after he resigned the presidency in disgrace in disgrace . Nixon's organized crime contacts continued even though he resigned in disgrace, sources say .
 Nixon’s golfing companions included Allen Dorfman, a mob-teamster financial coordinator, and Tony Provenzano, a former Teamster official and convicted Mafia killer .

 When Fidel Castro gained power in Cuba, Lansky was one of those mob chieftains who wanted him overthrown . Lansky wanted Castro overthrown. Lansky: "When Fidel Castro got power, he wanted him to be overthrown"

 Before the invasion could be launched, Nixon lost the 1960 election to John F Kennedy .

 Nixon was handily defeated, especially after news broke of a secret $200,000 loan from billionaire Howard Hughes to Nixon’s brother . Nixon was defeated after news of the loan broke .
 Within two years, Nixon was back on the political stage, campaigning for Republican candidates . Nixon was assassinated in 1968 . Nixon died in 1973 .

 During the Nixon years, his friends in organized crime were not forgotten . "During the Nixon . During the . Nixon . years, organized crime was not forgotten."

 In the thirty minutes following Kennedy’s assassination in Dallas, the Dow Jones average fell more than 21.16 points . A Killing on Wall Street: In the 30 minutes following JFK's assassination, the market fell .
 The Securities and Exchange Commission closed the stock exchange shortly after 2m., more than eighty minutes before normal closing time . The panic and confusion was such that the S&E closed the market after 2.30pm .
 It was the first emergency shutdown of the stock market since August 1933 . The shutdown was a first since August 1932 .
 A few sharp investors, or perhaps individuals with knowledge of what was to come, had taken "short" positions in scattered areas of the market .

 No one has publicly identified the men who made their own private killing in the stock market . It has been estimated that profits made on November 22 alone totaled more than $500 million .
