 Kennedy’s attempt to reform American society involves money . Another overlooked aspect of Kennedy's reform is money . Kennedy's efforts to reform society involve money .
 Abraham Lincoln found the big banks demanded high interest rates, from 24 to 36 percent, to fund the War Between the States . Lincoln found that interest rates were too high to pay for the war . Abraham Lincoln was forced to negotiate with the banks to lower rates .
 Rather than saddle the nation with unredeemable debt, he ordered the U.S. Treasury to issue new legal tender—United States notes . The United States notes are now legal tender .
 United States notes, the longest serving paper money in U.S. history, were fiat notes issued through the treasury backed only by faith in the federal government . The longest-serving paper money was issued in the United States during the Second World War .
 Under Lincoln’s orders, these new notes, popularly known as greenbacks, replaced demand notes . The new notes were made of greenbacks and were replaced by demand notes in 1863 .
 The greenback currency worked so well that political struggles and court cases continued into the late 1870s, when silver certificates again began to be issued . Silver certificates were issued again in the 1870s .
 Kennedy understood, as did Lincoln, that by returning to the Constitution, the soaring national debt could be reduced by not paying interest to the bankers of the Federal Reserve System . Only Congress shall coin and regulate money, the Constitution says .
 He signed Executive Order 11110 authorizing the Treasury Department to start printing and issuing silver certificates . The certificates are based on the remaining silver in the United States Treasury and the Commodity Credit Corporation .
 The authority vested in the President by paragraph of section 43 of the Act of May 12, 1933, as amended ) to issue silver certificates against any silver bullion, silver, or silver . dollars in the Treasury not then held for redemption of an outstanding silver certificates .
 There has been considerable confusion and misunderstanding over EO 11110 . There is also considerable confusion over what is known to be the law of the age of consent .
 JFK was making a surreptitious effort to return money-creation power from the privately owned Federal Reserve to the Treasury Department . From available evidence, there appears to be missing and even altered data .
 EO 11110 appeared to be a simple change to president Harry Truman’s Executive Order 10289 of 1951 . The change was made to the treasury through the issuance of treasury silver certificates .
 $100 million worth accumulated largely through reparations from World War I . This silver was to be put in storage under the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1933 and amended by the Gold Reserve Act of 1934 . The silver was expected to be stored in storage .
 The Commodity Credit Corporation and the Exchange Stabilization Fund were created . Some of the money was being used for purposes such as funding covert intelligence .
 EO 11110 would have allowed the treasury full access to silver certificates from the bowels of Fort Knox . It would have drastically lowered the U.S. government loan rate .
 JFK was seeking to ease the inflation rate and this one order would have accomplished just that . JFK sought to ease inflation rate . JFK was trying to ease just that. JFK was also trying to help ease inflation .
 This would have placed more silver into the general population and paid off debt to the Federal Reserve . The silver would have been placed into the public's hands and paid to the government .
 JFK's EO 11110 expanded the Treasury Department’s power to issue noninterest-bearing money from governmental reserves . The move edged out the United States need to approach the Federal Reserve to print more interest-bearing notes .
 EO 11110 allowed for the issuance of $4,292,893,815 in silverbacked treasury bills, called United States notes . The U.S. Treasury issued the bill for the first time in 18 years . The bill is now worth $4.2 billion .
 Kennedy also signed a bill changing the backing of $1 and $2 bills from silver to gold . The move adds strength to the weakening U.S. currency .
 President Kennedy’s successor, President Johnson, did nothing to change this situation . Kennedy's successor, JFK, did little to change the situation . President Johnson's administration has nothing to say .

 The deficit is more than $16 trillion, an all-time high . Today we continue to use interest-bearing Federal Reserve notes, and the deficit is $16 billion .
 Kennedy’s attempt to increase the monetary and credit supply by infusing the economy with U.S. notes issued through the treasury rather than the private interest-charging Federal Reserve System .
 Kennedy showed signs of attempting to undercut the power of the heretofore unassailable Federal Reserve System . Interest-free U.S. notes were indeed issued .
 Kennedy’s comptroller of the currency, James J Saxon, had been at odds with the powerful Federal Reserve Board for some time . He had been encouraging broader investment and lending powers for banks that were not part of the Reserve System .
 Saxon also had decided non-Reserve banks could underwrite state and local general obligation bonds, again weakening the dominant Federal Reserve banks . Saxon: Non-reserve banks can underwrite general obligation bond bonds .
 President Kennedy presented both his budget and proposals for tax reform that included a tax cut . Kennedy inched farther out on a limb with big business on January 17, 1963 .
 Kennedy’s tax proposals included relieving the tax burden of low-income and elderly persons, revising tax treatment of capital gains for a better flow of capital funds, and broadening the base of individual and corporate income taxes to remove special privileges and loopholes .
 This last possibility brought the beleaguered president into direct confrontation with one of the most powerful and single-minded groups in America—wealthy oilmen . The president's job is to deal with the world's largest oil companies, the White House says .
 The history of oil is replete with stories of unbounded greed, business chicanery, and even violence . Kennedy and Oilmen tell the tale of the oil industry's greed and violence .
 In 1923, the first major oil scandal occurred when it was discovered that president Warren G Harding’s secretary of the interior, Albert B Fall, accepted money from oilmen in exchange for secretly leasing drilling rights in Wyoming .
 There were calls to make the vital oil industry a public utility with governmental controls . By 1933, there were calls for the oil industry to be a government utility .
 Franklin Roosevelt’s secretary of the interior, Harold Ickes, supported the move . One of the men supporting this move was president Franklin Roosevelt's secretary of interior . The move was in response to a proposal by the White House to use the military to protect the environment .
 FDR was finally turned against the plan by Texas congressman Sam Rayburn, Lyndon Johnson’s mentor . Rayburn represented Texas oil interests in Washington .
 After World War II, the Marshall Plan began turning recovering European nations away from coal to oil . The Marshall Plan turned recovering countries away from oil to coal .
 In 1950, a secret agreement was reached between the State Department and major oil companies . It allowed all royalties paid to Arab nations to be applied as tax credits .
 The same year, a CIA-backed coup reinstated the Shah of Iran and new oil arrangements were made with Iran . The coup was the same year that the Shah was reinstated by the CIA .

 The Suez Crisis in 1956 signaled the end of British and French colonialism in the Middle East . The major oil companies moved to consolidate their power in the region .
 When John F Kennedy became president in 1961, the oil industry felt secure . The oil industry was secure when the president became president .
 President Kennedy began to assault the power of the oil giants directly, first with the Kennedy Act, and later by attacking the oil depletion allowance .
 Kennedy Act, passed on October 16, 1962, removed distinction between repatriated profits and profits reinvested abroad . Kennedy Act was passed in 1962 .
 The measure also was aimed at preventing taxable income from being hidden away in foreign subsidiaries and other tax havens . The measure was passed by Congress in March .
 Oil companies were greatly diversified with large overseas operations . While this law applied to industry as a whole, it particularly affected the oil companies .
 By the end of 1962, oilmen estimated their earnings on foreign investment capital would fall to 15 percent, compared with 30 percent in 1955 . Oilmen estimated that their earnings would fall from 30 percent to 15% in 1962 .
 The oil depletion allowance allowed oil producers to treat up to 27. percent of their income as tax exempt . The allowance was part of the most sacred of provisions in the eyes of oilmen . Oil depletion allowance was a key provision in the oil industry .
 In theory, this was to compensate for the depletion of fixed oil reserves . But, in effect, it gave the oil industry a lower tax rate .
 An oilman with a good deal of venture capital could become rich with virtually no risk . Under this allowance, an oilman can become rich without risk .
 If nine were dry holes and only the tenth struck oil, he would still make money because of tax breaks and the depletion allowance . If nine hit dry holes, only one struck oil and the tenth did, he still made money .
 It was estimated at the time that oilmen might lose nearly $300 million a year if the depletion allowance was diminished . The depletion allowance is estimated to be worth $300million a year .
 Attempts to eliminate or reduce the depletion allowance were rebuffed year after year by congressmen, many of whom were the happy recipients of oil-industry contributions .
 Kennedy’s tax package included provisions for closing a number of corporate tax loopholes, including the depletion allowance . Included in the tax package were provisions for . closing the . depletion allowance, which is a tax loophole, .
 Oilmen both in Texas and elsewhere felt threatened by Kennedy and his policies . Needless to say, oilmen felt threatened .

 Dallas oil geologist George DeMohrenschildt was the last-known close friend to Lee Harvey Oswald . He was identified by the Warren Commission as the last known friend to Oswald .
 DeMohrenschildt was friends with both Jackie Kennedy's family and her husband's alleged assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald . He is perhaps the most intriguing person in the entire cast of characters connected with the Kennedy assassination .
 Little was said about DeMohrenschildt at the time of the assassination as both he and his wife, Jeanne, were in Haiti during the events in Dallas .
 A close study of DeMohrenschildt’s life shows a string of intelligence connections, raising the possibility that he may have played a role — perhaps unwittingly — in furthering plans for the assassination .
 DeMohrenschildt's suspicious death may have come to haunt him in the days just prior to his suspicious death in 1977 .
 DeMohrenschildt was born April 17, 1911, in Mozyr, a small Baltic town in czarist Russia near the Polish border . His family, originally named Mohrenskuld, was of Swedish extraction; he was born in 1911 .
 An educated, sophisticated young man, DeMohrenschildt was introduced to many wealthy and influential Americans . He met many wealthy Americans .
 Bouvier is Jacqueline Kennedy’s mother, also her father and her whole family . Bouvier was in the process of getting a divorce from her husband when she met him, also Jacqueline .
 I met Jackie then, when she was a little girl. her sister, who was still in the cradle practically . Her sister, Jackie, was also a child, but she was never in the same shape .
 DeMohrenschildt traveled by bus to Texas, where he got a job with Humble Oil Company . After failing in attempts to sell insurance and perfume, he moved to Houston, Texas .
 Young DeMohrenschildt was confined to working as a ‘roughneck’ in the Louisiana oil fields . He was friends with the chairman of the board of Humble .
 For years he claimed to have worked for French intelligence during the early years of World War II . He said he was never an official agent but had helped a good friend, Pierre Freyss, the head of French counterintelligence .
 In 1941, he was atrested by the FBI and charged with being a Nazi spy for sketching and photographing military installations near Aransas Pass, Texas . He was arrested in 1941 and charged .
 In later years he confessed to his wife that he had briefly worked for the Germans . He later confessed to the wife he had worked for them .
 DeMohrenschildt also became closely connected with exiled Russians who joined with the General Vlassov movement, anticommunist Russians who fought with the Nazis .
 Russian exile communities were springing up in cities with large exile communities . They referred to themselves as “solidarists,” indicating the solidarity of their purpose .
 One of these groups existed in Dallas during the early 1960s . DeMohrenschildt disclaimed being a member .
 The Vlassov organization was eventually absorbed by the Nazi spy system under General Reinhard Gehlen . At the end of the war the system became a part of United States intelligence .
 DeMohrenschildt’s oil-related travels took him to France, Nigeria, Ghana, and Togoland . He traveled to Ghana, France, Ghana and France .
 In 1957, despite an unflattering background check by the CIA, he journeyed to Yugoslavia for the International Cooperation Administration, a branch of the U.S. government’s Agency for International Development .
 DeMohrenschildt apparently had some association with the agency, according to documents . Documents that became public in the late 1970s were made public .
 CIA memo indicated that DeMohrenschildt also furnished lengthy reports on his later travels through Mexico and Central America . CIA memo said he also provided lengthy reports of his travels .
 Shortly before leaving for Yugoslavia, DeMohrenschildt met another Russian exile who lived in the same Dallas hotel with him . Shortly before he left for Yugoslavia he met another exile .
 Jeanne Fromenke LeGon had already established a career as a dancer and clothing designer . She was also a clothing designer and dancer .
 Her Russian father built the first railroads in China and was connected with Nationalist politics there . Her brother, Sergio, had worked on the super-secret Manhattan atomic bomb project .

 Douglass drew the term “unspeakable” from Thomas Merton, an ordained Catholic priest turned Trappist monk . Douglass was a member of the Trappists, who lived in Trappism-inspired Trappisms .
 The term refers to a hidden but insidious ideology of fascism that has so permeated American society that it must remain unmentioned in public . It must be unspoken in public to discuss fascism in the U.S.
 Douglass wrote, “The Vietnam War, the race to a global war, and the interlocking murders of John Kennedy, Malcolm X, Martin Luther King, and Robert Kennedy were all signs of the Unspeakable.”

 In Dallas on the day Kennedy died some people were iconoclastic enough to suggest that Vice President Johnson was behind the assassination . All the Way with LBJ: The Vice President of the Confederacy .
 These were mostly longtime Texas residents who had heard vicious stories about Johnson . They knew the Texas politician had more to gain from Kennedy’s death than just about anyone .

 Lyndon Baines Johnson was born August 27, 1908, near Johnson City, Texas . His grandfather, one of the area’s original settlers, was named for his grandfather .
 Johnson graduated from Johnson City High School as president of his senior class of six . Young Johnson graduated with a class of 6 in his class .
 He hitchhiked back home and enrolled at Southwest Texas State Teachers College at San Marcos . After running away to California, he hitch-iked back to Texas and enrolled .
 After graduating at age twenty-two, Johnson got a teaching job in Houston, but it failed to hold the interest of this ambitious young man . Johnson graduated at the age of twenty-22 .
 In 1931, Johnson was drawn into Texas politics, campaigning strenuously for conservative congressman Richard M Kleberg . Johnson was elected to Congress in 1931 .
 Johnson accompanied Kleberg to Washington as his secretary . After Kleberg’s victory, Johnson accompanied him to Washington . Johnson was Johnson's secretary .
 In 1934 Johnson met Claudia Alta Taylor, the daughter of an affluent merchant and landowner in Karnack, Texas . Johnson was visiting in Austin when he met an attractive twenty-year-old journalism student .
 After a whirlwind courtship of two months, Johnson returned to Texas and asked "Bird" to marry him . Johnson's courtship consisted mainly of daily telephone calls from Washington .
 She agreed and the couple drove to San Antonio for a rushed wedding in St. Antonio . The couple got married in a rushed ceremony in San Antonio .
 After a honeymoon in Mexico, the Johnsons moved to Washington, where they rented a one-bedroom apartment . Johnson resumed his political work for Kleberg in Washington .
 Johnson was a close friend of congressman Sam Rayburn . Rayburn was already a power on Capitol Hill . He was a friend of the Johnson family .
 President Roosevelt named Johnson as Texas director of the National Youth Administration in 1935 . The program was a New Deal program for employing youngsters in the 1930s .
 Johnson created a formidable political base in south Texas . He used his authority to award loans and jobs to create jobs .
 In early 1937, with the sudden death of Austin congressman James P Buchanan, Johnson saw an opportunity to advance . Johnson saw the death of Buchanan as a chance to advance in Texas .
 Austin attorney Alvin Wirtz and his client Herman Brown were looking for help in Washington . Johnson was looking for financial and political support to make a bid for Buchanan’s seat .
 Brown’s construction company, Brown & Root, had already spent millions building the Marshall Ford Dam in south Texas . Brown and Root's construction company had already built millions of dollars in Marshall Ford dam .
 The project had not been officially authorized by Congress; rather it had begun as a government grant obtained by Buchanan . Buchanan had begun the project with a grant from Congress .
 The indefatigable Johnson pledged total support of Roosevelt and his New Deal . Wirtz, Brown, and their well-heeled business associates, backed Johnson .
 The senatorial election climaxed with a raging blizzard and sudden surgery for LBJ to repair a ruptured appendix . LBJ outpolled five opponents by 3,000 votes . The blizzard ended with a victory, with Johnson outpolling five opponents .
 Johnson managed to get authorization for the dam project as well as a contract for Brown & Root to build a huge Navy base at Corpus Christi . Johnson also got authorization for a massive Navy base .
 Herman Brown and his friends were so pleased with Johnson’s performance that in 1940 the young congressman was offered a share in very lucrative oil properties with no money down . In 1940, Johnson was able to earn a share of lucrative properties without money down in oil properties .
 Brown realized even at that time that Johnson’s true political goal was the presidency . Brown realized that both a House and a Senate seat would come from Texas's reliable oil and gas constituency, Brown said .
 As a congressman, Johnson continued to perform for his oil and business mentors back in Texas . Johnson was a congressman .
 Just two days after Pearl Harbor, Johnson was called to active duty . Johnson was the first congressman to leave for military service .
 Roosevelt called on all congressmen serving in the armed forces to return home . After serving less than a year, Johnson returned to Washington after less than one year .
 Johnson was accepted by powerful House Speaker Sam Rayburn . After a period of cool relations due to Johnson’s ambitiousness, he again was accepted . Johnson was elected to the House of Representatives .

 Stevenson didn't have a clear majority, so a runoff election was called for August 28 . Stevenson didn’t have clear majority in the August 28 election .

 Richard Case Nagell told one of the strangest and most sinister stories to come out of the Kennedy assassination . The man’s name was Richard Case . He told the story of the assassination .
 Nagell entered the Army in 1948 at age eighteen . Raised in orphanage and foster homes, he was raised in foster homes and orphanage .
 During the Korean War, he was the youngest American to receive a battlefield commission . He was also the youngest U.S. soldier to receive battlefield commission in the war .
 He was awarded three Purple Hearts and a Bronze Star while serving in Korea . He was honorably discharged in 1959 with the rank of captain .
 Military papers disclosed that Nagell graduated from Army Military Intelligence School and a special leader’s course . He served in the Counterintelligence Corps .
 According to his records, he was given a top-secret security clearance in 1950 . He was given the clearance in 1952, according to records .
 Nagell was "loaned" to "another intelligence agency" for assignments in Asia in 1958, testimony says . He was part of a spy group called Field Operations Intelligence . Courtroom testimony says he was sent to Asia by military intelligence .
 As a senior intelligence adviser in South Korea, Nagell admitted participating in political assassinations, kidnapping, blackmailing, and counterfeiting operations . He admitted to participating in kidnappings, kidnappings and assassinations .
 By 1957, he had told superiors he was “fed up” with committing crimes in the name of national security . He was reassigned to counterintelligence duties in Japan . By 1957 he had been reassigned .
 It was here, he said, he first met a young Marine stationed at Atsugi named Lee Harvey Oswald . Oswald was a Marine stationed in Atsugai, Japan .
 About this time, Nagell married a Japanese woman and, at her urging, resigned his commission . He returned to the United States, and went to work for the State of California .
 In 1962, amid marital problems, he left his wife and two children and journeyed to Mexico City . He left his family and children in Mexico City amid marital issues .
 In Mexico, Nagell said he contacted a CIA man he had previously known and signed a contract with the agency, becoming a double agent . He contacted the CIA man in Mexico, he said, and became a CIA agent .
 The Soviets informed him of a plot to kill Kennedy involving the violent anti-Castro Cuban group known as Alpha 66 . Nagell was ordered to return to the United States to learn more about the plot .
 Nagell was shocked to find it was his old acquaintance Lee Harvey Oswald . Oswald had been Oswald's friend in the Army in the early days of the Second World War . Oswald was the leader of the anti-war movement .
 Nagell said he became aware of at least two Kennedy assassination plots during this time . Both plots involved Cubans whose “war names” were “Angel” and “Leopaldo,” the same names given to Silvia Odio .
 According to Nagell, the CIA-backed Alpha 66 Cubans convinced Oswald they were members of Castro’s intelligence service and solicited his help in assassinating Kennedy to avenge CIA assassination plots against Castro .
 Evidence suggests Oswald was actually playing as an undercover agent of the United States . Oswald would have gone along with these schemes to learn all he could about the plots, he says .
 Nagell said he actually got close enough to the plotting to tape a New Orleans meeting in late August 1963 . He said he got close to the plot to tape the meeting in New Orleans .
 Nagell was ordered by KGB officials fearful of being implicated in an assassination to disrupt the Kennedy plot . He was then ordered to persuade Oswald that the deal was phony and if this didn’t work, to get rid of him .
 Nagell said he met Oswald in early September in New Orleans’s Jackson Square . Oswald was a member of a group that organized a civil war .

 In 1974, Richard Lester, using a metal detector, discovered a bullet fragment on the far south side of Dealey Plaza just east of the Triple Underpass . The fragment was found by Lester in 1974 . Lester used the metal detector .
 The fragment was later studied by firearms experts of the House Select Committee on Assassinations who determined through ballistics that while the fragment was from 6.5-millimeter ammunition, it had not been fired through Oswald rifle .
 The FBI and committee left the impression that this discovery had no connection with Kennedy’s death . Rather than view this as evidence that perhaps multiple rifles were used in the assassination, both the FBI and the committee said this discovery was not connected to Kennedy's death .
 An intact .45-caliber bullet was discovered in May 1976 by Hal Luster buried in dirt by the four-foot-high cement retaining wall near where Abraham Zapruder stood filming .

 Rifle experts have explained that this is evidence that a sabot may have been used to fire ammunition from a 30.06 rifle . Rifle experts say this may be evidence of a sabot being used to shoot ammunition from the 30 .06 rifle.
 A sabot, also called a husk, is a plastic sleeve that allows a larger-caliber weapon to fire a smallercaliber slug . A sabot is also known as a sabot, or husk .
 The results of using a lighter-weight slug include increased velocity, producing more accuracy and greater striking power . The results also included increased velocity and more striking power.
 The smaller slug exhibits the ballistics of the weapon it was originally fired from, rather than the 30.06, as the sabot engages the 30 .06’s rifling . And the smaller slug shows that it was fired from the weapon originally fired .
 Assassination conspirators could have fired 6.5-millimeter bullets from Oswald rifle into water, recovered them, reloaded them into the more accurate and powerful 30.06 with the use of a sabot . The sabot is held in place by crimping the cartridge, which is held
 By this method, bullet fragments found in the limousine would have the ballistics of Oswald’s rifle rather than the 30.06 from which they were actually fired . The method is similar to that of the 30 .06 .

 The slug can be reloaded and refired using a sabot, which comes apart on firing . It is just such a slug that can be refired and reloaded with a sabot .

 A limousine sped past a parked car parked on the grass on the north side of Elm Street near the west side of the underpass . The car was seen speeding past the parked car .
 He came down that grassy slope on the west side of the Triple Underpass, on the Elm Street side . It's not the first time he has come down that slope .
 "He threw something in the back seat and went around the front hurriedly and got in the car and took off," he said . "And, he threw something ... and went out hurriedly," he added .
 I was on Commerce Street right there across from , fixing to go under the Triple Underpass going into town . I was right there on Commerce St. across from . The triple underpass is under construction .
 I saw all this and I said, “That doesn’t make sense, everybody running to the scene and one person running from it.” "That doesn't make sense," he said .
 "I speeded up and went through the Triple Underpass up to Houston .. . made a left .. . back on Main .. . and caught up with him because he got caught on a light. So, I speed up . So, he sped up . and went . through the
 I told my daughter to get a pencil and some paper and write down what I tell you. I told her to get some paper . "I told her she should write it down," she said .
 By this time, we had gotten to the toll road [formerly the Dallas-Fort Worth Turnpike, now Interstate 30] going toward Fort Worth . The toll road is now known as Interstate 30 .
 I got the license number and description of the car and I saw what the man looked like. I got a license number . I also got a description of a man in the car . It's not clear what happened to the driver .
 "I got the license number and all and exited off the turnpike and came back and picked up my other daughter down there at Commerce and Houston," she says .
 "I called in the information on the license number and what I had seen. Then I went to a phone and called in a phone," she says . "I went to the phone to get the information," she adds .
 Tilson’s story is corroborated by his daughter Judy Ladner . Photos taken west of the Triple Underpass at the time do not show the black car . Tilson says he was killed in a car crash .

 Tilson threw away the scrap of paper with the license number on it . Tilson believed he had done his duty and threw it away .
 It was only much later that he discovered that his information had been ignored . He later discovered that he had been told his information was ignored .

 Deputy sheriff Roger Craig thought he saw a suspect flee the scene in a station wagon . Jean Hill was taken by men in suits to the sheriff’s office .
 In 1963, Roger Dean Craig was an ambitious young deputy sheriff who was going places . The Account of Roger Craig is published by CNN.com.com/Heroes .
 Craig Craig had run away from his Wisconsin home at age twelve . Craig had received a high school diploma on his own and had served honorably in the U.S. Army .
 By 1959 he had married and taken a job as a sheriff’s deputy in Dallas, Texas . By 1959, he had been married .
 Craig already had received four promotions within the Dallas County Sheriff’s Department . Craig had been named Officer of the Year by the Dallas Traffic Commission in 1960 .
 Craig's account of his experiences that day caused considerable problems for the official version of the assassination’s aftermath . Craig: "Craig's account was very different than the official account of that day" Craig: Craig's accounts have caused some of the most significant problems in the history of

 He began questioning people when he noticed a woman in her early thirties attempting to drive out of the parking lot . He began to question people after he noticed she was trying to leave the lot .
 The sheriff rented parking space by the month to deputies who worked in the courthouse, except for official vehicles . He, in turn, rented parking spaces to deputies working at the courthouse .
 I had no way of knowing that an officer with whom I had worked for four years was capable of losing a thirty-year-old woman and a three-thousand-pound automobile . I had been with the officer for 4 years, he said .
 To this day, Officer Lewis does not know who she was, where she came from, or what happened to her . Officer Lewis says she is still unsure of her identity .

 I tried to get across Elm Street to stop the car and talk with subjects, but the traffic was so heavy I could not make it . The traffic was too heavy for me to make it across the road .

 Support for Craig came in 1992 with the public release of Dallas Police files on the case . Police files were released in 1992 and Craig was found guilty .
 Ruth Paine attempted to visit Marina Oswald, Marina Oswald . Paine was a member of Paine’s family . Oswald was the only person to contact Paine .
 Craig and Arnold Rowland's testimony began to cause problems for Craig within the Sheriff’s Department . His insistence on sticking with his story despite repeated attempts by authorities to have both Rowland and Craig change their testimony caused problems for the department .
 Craig’s credibility began to slip within the department and on July 4, 1967, he was fired by Decker . Craig was fired from the police force in 1967 .
 Some say the cause was laxity and improprieties in his work . Others say it was due to his unyielding position on the assassination .
 In recent years there seems to be growing corroboration for Craig’s story . Craig's story is believed to be the subject of numerous investigations .

 His wife left him, some say due to pressure over his involvement in the assassination, and his back was injured in a car accident . Some say he was left with a back injury and his wife left for him . His back was hurt in an accident .
 His original account of his experiences began to grow in detail and complexity as he sought acceptance for his story . He began to write about his experiences as a child .
 On May 15, 1975, Roger Craig, then only thirty-nine years old, was killed by a rifle bullet . Craig was shot in the head by a sniper sniper in 1975 .

 Their route took them past the Depository and across the eastern portion of Dealey Plaza . Their route included the eastern part of Dealy Plaza .

 In later years Colonel L Fletcher Prouty, who as chief of special operations for the Joint Chiefs of Staff under President Kennedy acted as liaison with the CIA, stated his immediate superior, General Edward Lansdale, was photographed walking by the tramps in Dealey Plaza and perhaps even passing
 Lansdale was Kennedy’s assistant secretary of defense for special operations . He was the ranking member of Operation Mongoose, the secret war against Castro to include assassinations . Lansdale served as Kennedy's deputy defense secretary for the CIA .
 Prouty’s identification of Lansdale was corroborated in a 1985 letter to Marine Lieutenant General Victor H Kurlak, the special assistant for counterinsurgency activities of the Joint Chiefs of Staff .
 The three tramps were taken into custody by the sheriff’s office . Once in custody, the tramps officially disappeared .
 Names, information, or fingerprints taken were not seen before 1992 . Although reportedly transferred later to the Dallas police station, they reportedly were never booked .
 Dallas police arrest records for November 22, 1963, compiled for the Warren Commission, were missing . The House Subcommittee on Government Information and Individual Rights discovered in 1975 that Dallas arrest records had been missing .
 Photos show the men had recent haircuts, shined shoes, and old but unsoiled clothing . Although they were labeled “tramps,” photos show they had recent haircuts and clean clothes .
 In 1976 the three tramps drew national attention when comedian/social activist Dick Gregory and others claimed that two of the men were CIA operatives and Watergate conspirators E Howard Hunt and Frank Sturgis . In 1976, Dick Gregory claimed that the three men were none other than CIA operatives E
 E Howard Hunt lost a libel court case based on a national article that claimed CIA documents indicated he was in Dallas the day of the assassination . Hunt lost the case in the summer of 1985 . Hunt was sued for libel .
 Other CIA connections include Thomas Vallee, Fred Lee Chrisman, and Daniel Carswell . Other men with CIA connections also have been named .
 In 1991 Lois Gibson, a forensic facial recognition expert with the Houston Police Department, stated publicly that an investigation convinced her the three tramps were Harrelson; Charles Frederick Rogers, also known as Richard Montoya, who was wanted for the 1965 murder of his parents .
 Holt, located in California, gave a convincing, if not provable, account of his role in the assassination . Holt was located in the U.S. State Department of Justice .
 Holt said he delivered phony Secret Service identification to Dallas before the assassination in the company of Harrelson . Holt: He delivered phony ID to Dallas in the days before the shooting .
 Those who might have vouched for Holt's story were either dead or missing . Like so many other instances in the assassination case, Holt's friends and family members were also missing or dead . Holt's friend and family were among those who might be witnesses .
 The Dallas City Council in 1992 decided to open their old police files in which suddenly were found three arrest records naming the three tramps as a Harold Doyle, John Forester Gedney, and Gus W Abrams .
 Abrams was dead but Doyle and Gedney were located in Oregon and Florida . Both said they indeed were arrested in Dallas on November 22, 1963 . Abrams was found dead in Dallas .
 The FBI looked into the matter and a report later in 1992 described how the three men had arrived by rail in Dallas early on the morning of the assassination . The FBI investigated the matter .
 The trio was arrested by Dallas police in a gondola car on Irving Street . After showering and receiving fresh clothes and a meal from a mission, they were arrested by police .
 The three were convicted of vagrancy and sentenced to six days in jail only to be released four days later due to overcrowding . According to this report, the three were released due to the overcrowding of jail .
 The trio were pulled out of the train cars only moments after the assassination . The pictures were made long after the 12:30m. shooting .
 The three arrest reports, all written and signed by the same Officer Chambers, gave an arrest time of 4m . The three arrests were made by Chambers, all signed by Chambers .
 There were no jail records or court hearings concerning the trio . Other than the three reports, there were no court records .
 Charles Voyde Harrelson is a convicted hit man with independent evidence to support the idea that he was involved . Plus, the story of the three railroad tramps left no room for the convicted hitman .
 Harrelson had a long history of involvement with Dallas underworld characters linked directly to Jack Ruby . He was twice convicted of murder for hire .
 He had been identified as a suspect in the death of federal judge John Wood of San Antonio, Texas . Wood was shot in an ambush by a highpowered rifle .
 Harrelson held lawmen at bay for six hours . High on cocaine, he held a pistol to his own head and pointed it to his head .
 During this time, according to the arresting officers, he not only confessed to the Judge Wood killing, but also claimed he had participated in the Kennedy assassination . During the time he was arrested, he also claimed to have killed Judge Wood .
 The late Fort Worth graphics expert Jack White, who testified before the House Select Committee on Assassinations, already had noticed the resemblance of Harrelson to the youngest tramp . White's testimony was in response to a hearing before the committee .
 Harrelson was forty-seven years old in 1985, making him twenty-five at the time of the assassination . The actor was twenty-six years old when he was assassinated .
 This corresponds with the age of the youngest tramp, who was thought to have been between twenty-five and thirty years old . The tramp is thought to be between 25 and 30 years old, according to reports .

 Further evidence suggests Harrelson may have played a role in the assassination . The actor's photograph with that of the youngest tramp was compared to that of a tramp .
 In subsequent interviews, Harrelson admitted to being a close friend of Matthews . Matthews died in 2010 .
 Russell Douglas Matthews is mentioned in the Warren Report as a ‘passing acquaintance’ of Jack Ruby’s . Matthews is obliquely connected with a Ruby-backed jeep sale to Cuba in 1959 . Matthews mentioned as a former Dallas underworld character .
 The committee also documented Matthews’s connections to Dallas gamblers Lewis McWillie, that close friend to the Kirkwoods of Fort Worth, and Benny Binion .
 The committee further developed evidence that Matthews was in contact with associates of Florida crime chieftain Santos Trafficante Jr. and was linked to Texas underworld characters such as Hollis de Lois Green and Jettie Bass .
 Matthews was best man at the wedding of a Dallas underworld figure named George McGann to Beverly Oliver . In a strange sidelight, Matthews was also best man in the wedding .
 The former chief counsel of the House committee, G Robert Blakey, in his book The Plot to Kill the President, reiterated the committee’s findings that Kennedy was assassinated as the result of a conspiracy involving organized crime and more than one gunman was involved .
 If organized crime in Dallas was involved, then the entire spectrum of the Dallas underworld becomes suspect . Ruby’s role would seem to justify that conclusion .
 There is evidence that Harrelson’s contacts went far beyond Dallas police characters . The actor's contacts with Dallas police officers went beyond Dallas officers .
 Indicted along with Harrelson in the plot to kill Judge Wood was the brother of reputed New Orleans crime boss Carlos Marcello, another of the organized crime figures the House Select Committee on Assassinations named as possibly involved .
 There was also involvement with criminals connected to intelligence agencies and even the military .
 The Company, which according to lawmen took its nickname from the CIA, involved more than three hundred persons, many ex-police or ex-military men .
 Federal drug agents said the group imported billions of dollars’ worth of narcotics from Central and South America as well as conducting gunrunning and mercenary operations . The group is accused of operating a gunrunning operation and gunrunning .
 Federal prosecutors claimed The Company owned more than $30 million in assets such as planes, ships, and real estate . During one criminal trial involving members of the group, federal prosecutors said The Company had assets worth millions .
 Florida lawmen investigating this group claimed Harrelson was a member of it . Jimmy Chagra, the man who allegedly hired the man to kill the judge, also once hired The Company for protection .

 Researchers find it remarkable that a man reputed to be a high-ranking mobster by government agents should hire Harrelson on this claim rather than boot him out of his office . Everyone had been told the assassination was caused by only a lone nut .
 Harrelson died in prison in 2007 while serving a life sentence in the Wood assassination . He was never interviewed thoroughly about his role in Dallas . His son's acting career prospered .

 Braden/Brading was a man with a police record stretching back to 1934 for such crimes as burglary, embezzlement, mail fraud, and conspiracy, including several arrests in Dallas . He was arrested in Dallas, Texas .
 Braden had informed his parole officer that he would be in Dallas from November 21 to 25, 1963 . Braden was on parole in California for mail fraud and interstate transportation of stolen property .
 Jack Ruby also was at the Hunt offices about that same time, ostensibly to help a young woman get a job . Jack Ruby was also there to help the young woman .
 Both Braden and Ruby denied these visits, though they have been verified by more than one office worker . Both men have denied the visits .
 Braden, along with ex-convict Morgan Brown, were staying at the Cabana Motel, the same motel Ruby visited the night of November 21 . Braden and Brown were staying in the same hotel as Ruby .

 First Braden said he made the trip to Dallas from California and met with a Dallas parole officer at the moment of the assassination . Braden says he met with the parole officer before the assassination at the time of the shooting .
 If Braden had not notified his parole office that he was leaving California, he would have been in violation of parole and subject to arrest . Braden's parole office said he would be in violation if he left California .
 Braden told the committee he walked as far as the Dal-Tex Building in an effort to find a telephone so he could call his mother and tell her about the assassination . Braden said he walked out of the building to find out what happened to his mother .
 Braden lied and was among the spectators gathered in Dealey Plaza minutes after the shooting . Braden has definitely been identified in photos of him in the photographs . It is now widely accepted that Braden was among those gathered in the crowd .
 A known felon with ties to Mafia figures, New Orleans, and Jack Ruby would be hanging around Dealey Plaza just after Kennedy’s death . This fact alone creates deep suspicion about the immediate Dallas investigation and the subsequent federal investigation .
 In 1976, the National Archives revealed that at least two documents relating to the Braden arrest were missing . This suspicion is heightened in light of the fact that in 1976, two documents related to the arrest of Braden were missing from the archives .
 One of the oddest arrests that day was reported only in a Dallas newspaper . The arrests were made in Dallas .
 The November 22, 1963, edition of the Dallas Times Herald reported that a policeman arrested a man wearing horn-rimmed glasses, a plaid coat, and a raincoat after Depository employees pointed to him from a third-floor window .
 Jack Lawrence's arrest is an odd arrest that deserves more serious study . Another odd arrest, that of Jack Lawrence, also deserves serious consideration .
 Lawrence was arrested late on the afternoon on November 22, 1963, after his actions caused suspicions among his coworkers at Downtown LincolnMercury, located two blocks west of Dealey Plaza .
 Lawrence had obtained a job as a car salesman at the dealership just one month before the assassination with job references from New Orleans that later were found to be phony . Lawrence obtained the job with references to New Orleans from a New Orleans car salesman .
 About thirty minutes after the assassination, he came hustling through the company’s showroom, pale and sweating . However, about thirty minutes later, he returned to the showroom .
 He told coworkers he had been ill that morning and that he had tried to drive the car back to the dealership but had to park it due to the heavy traffic . He said he was ill and had been unable to drive it back to dealership due to traffic .
 Later, employees found the car parked behind the picket fence on top of the Grassy Knoll overlooking Dealey Plaza .
 Lawrence’s activities were so suspicious that employees called police, who picked him up that evening . Lawrence was picked up by police that evening after his activities became suspicious .
 Lawrence reportedly was an expert marksman in the Air Force . Lawrence reportedly left Dallas after being released the next day . Lawrence was reportedly released from Dallas hospital .
 In 1991, researcher Sheldon Inkol detailed Lawrence’s story in The Third Decade, a JFK assassination newsletter . Inkol received a call from Lawrence, whom he described as “intelligent, articulate and good-humored” but irate .
 He denied any role in the assassination and said he parked his ‘loaner’ car at the intersection of Ervay and Main Streets due to traffic and hurried to the car dealership so as not to be late .
 Dallas that day was flooded with all kinds of people who ended up there for some reason . Dallas was flooded that day with people from all over the world .
 Dallas police nabbed Lee Harvey Oswald less than an hour and a half after the assassination . Oswald's arrest was the most prominent arrest of that day .
 Dallas policeman Jefferson Davis Tippit has received less attention than most others . The Dallas police officer was killed in the Kennedy assassination in 1968 .
 Allegedly Tippit was shot down while attempting to arrest Lee Harvey Oswald forty-five minutes after the assassination in Oak Cliff, south of downtown Dallas . Allegedly he was trying to arrest Oswald .
 It was the slaying of a policeman that led to Oswald’s arrest and became a cornerstone of the case . Oswald's arrest led to his arrest and led to the conviction of Oswald's guilt .
 A growing body of evidence suggests that Oswald did not kill Tippit, which, if true, reverses the above argument . If true, perhaps he didn't shoot the president, then perhaps he did not shoot the policeman .
 Tippit, the policeman and the man, is a one-dimensional and insubstantial figure—unknown and unknowable . The policeman and man are one of the characters in the film .
 The Commission was not interested in Tippit’s life, and apparently interested in his death only to the extent that it could be ascribed to Oswald, despite massive defects in the evidence against him . The Commission did not want to look at Tippits' life, but
 The commission failed to mention that Tippit's death occurred only two blocks from Ruby's home . Ruby’s home on Marsalis Street was two blocks away from the site of his death .
 The Warren Commission concluded that Oswald was Oswald's killer . Yet with no real knowledge of Tippit’s background or associations, there were many problems with the evidence . The commission concluded with little or no knowledge of the background of Oswald's associations .
 The chief witness for the Warren Commission was Helen Markham, whose credibility was strained to the breaking point . Markham's credibility, even at the time of the Commission, was strained .
 Markham claimed to have talked for some time with the dying Tippit, yet medical authorities said he was killed instantly . Markham said he talked to the dying man, but authorities said that he was dead instantly .
 She said she saw Tippit's killer talk with the policeman through his patrol car's right-hand window . But pictures taken at the scene show that window was shut, she said .
 She was in hysterics at the time and even left her shoes on top of Tippit's car .
 Witnesses at the scene claim they never saw Markham in the minutes following the shooting . Other witnesses say they did not .
 Cabdriver Scoggins also identified Oswald that day, although he admitted he did not actually witness the shooting . Oswald's view of the fleeing killer was obscured because he ducked down behind his cab as he came by .
 Scoggins and cabdriver William Whaley viewed a Dallas police lineup composed of five “young teenagers” and Oswald . Whaley allegedly drove Oswald home that day that day .
 "Anybody who wasn’t sure could have picked out the right one just for that," he said .
 The suspect had conspicuous bruises and a black eye . Oswald's protestations weren’t enough to guide the witnesses in identifying Oswald .
 Oswald stated during the lineup he was asked his name and place of employment . Oswald said he was not asked his job at the time of his arrest . Oswald was arrested in connection with the shooting . Oswald has been charged with multiple counts of murder .

 Charles A Crenshaw retired as chairman emeritus of the Department of Surgery at Fort Worth’s Peter Smith Hospital . He was also a director of the Tarrant County Hospital District and a surgeon at the hospital .

 It is a small autopsy room, and when you are called in circumstances like that to look at the wound of the President of the United States who is dead, you don't look around too much to ask people for their names and take notes on who they are .

 Young streetwise Sparky gained a reputation with his fists, although accounts of his aggressiveness differed with those who knew him .
 Barney Rasofsky, who gained fame in the 1930s as World Welterweight Boxing Champion Barney Ross, in 1964 told the FBI that he and Ruby along with other young toughs were paid $1 per trip to deliver sealed envelopes for Al Capone .
 If this information was passed along to the Warren Commission, it was never reported . The Warren Commission never passed along with the information .
 Rasofsky also said Ruby was never a troublemaker, although he always was ready to defend himself against any attack . Ruby was always a ready-to-defend himself .
 These recollections clash markedly with those of others who recalled Ruby as a street brawler . Others recall him as eager to take up any challenge, even to the extent of aiding someone else in trouble . Ruby's memory is mixed with those who remember him as a tough guy .

 In 1936, he was still in San Francisco living for a brief time with his sister Eva and her husband . He was still living with Eva and their husband when he died .
 Ruby later told authorities he returned to Chicago in 1937— the same year his mother was committed to Elgin State Hospital with mental disorders . Despite some evidence, Ruby said he returned in 1937 . Ruby later said his mother died in Elgin, Illinois .

 Ruby began working for the Scrap Iron and Junk Handlers Union in 1937 . He returned to Chicago about 1937, according to Social Security Administration records .
 Chicago attorney Leon R Cooke, a close friend to Ruby, had founded the union and was financial secretary . Ruby died at the age of 92 .
 When gangsters took control of the union and its funds, Ruby went along . Ruby's union was taken over by gangsters connected to the Chicago underworld . Ruby was a member of a union in Chicago .
 Union president John Martin, who earlier had been indicted along with a major Chicago mobster for withholding tax information, named young Rubenstein union secretary . Rubenstein was named secretary of the union .

 Martin fatally shot Cooke in the union’s offices after an argument over missing funds . Cooke was shot by Martin in December 1939 . Martin shot Cooke to death in a dispute over funds .
 Martin claimed self-defense and never served time for the murder of Cooke . Cooke was shot in the back, Martin said he was defending himself in self-defence . Martin was convicted of the murder but never served a prison sentence .
 Ruby claimed such close friendship for the slain man that he eventually took the name Leon as his own middle name . Ruby stayed on with the corrupt union after Cooke’s brutal murder .
 Following the bad publicity over Cooke’s killing, the union was reorganized as the Waste Material Handlers Union, Local 20467 .
 Martin was replaced and the reorganized union was dominated by its secretary-treasurer, Paul J Dorfman, a man with long-standing connections to Chicago racketeers . Dorfman was replaced by Martin and the union was reorganized by Dorfman .
 By mid-1943, Ruby had found a permanent home in the U.S. Army Air Corps . Ruby was a major success for the Army Air Force .
 At the beginning of World War II, he had been granted a draft deferment for reasons not entirely clear . He was granted the deferment at the start of WWII for reasons unknown .
 One version is that Rubenstein feigned a hearing disability by wearing a hearing aid . Another is that he was granted an ‘economic hardship” deferment because he was the only Rubenstein child remaining at home .
 Despite an appeal to his local board, he was inducted into the Army Air Corps on May 21, 1943 .
 Ruby returned to Chicago after his discharge from the air force in 1946 . He entered an unsuccessful sales business with his brothers, Hyman, Sam, and Earl .
 As in their childhood, the four Rubenstein brothers constantly argued with one another . This time, they were arguing over how to run the business . As in childhood, they argued with each other .
 One of the few things they agreed on was the need to obtain a more “American” name .
 After Hyman left the business, Sam, Earl, and Jack all shortened their name from Rubenstein to Ruby .

 Jack's name change was made official by a decree from the 68th Judicial District Court of Dallas on December 30, 1947 . Jack arrived in Dallas shortly after his arrival .
 The official story of Ruby’s move is that he went to help his sister operate a nightclub . Some sources have claimed that Ruby was part of a plan to bring Dallas rackets under the control of the Chicago underworld .

 The Warren Commission was quietly notified in early 1964 that the bureau had contacted Jack Ruby in 1959 as an informant . The bureau asked that the Commission keep this explosive fact a secret . Jack Ruby was an informant for the Warren Commission in 1959 .
 The contents of this February 27, 1964, memo from Director Hoover to Warren Commission general counsel J Lee Rankin was not made public until 1975 . Hoover's memo was sent to Rankin from the Warren Commission .
 Ruby was contacted by an Agent of the Dallas Office on March 11, 1959, in view of his position as a nightclub operator who might have knowledge of the criminal element in Dallas, Texas .
 He was advised of the Bureau’s jurisdiction in criminal matters, and he expressed a willingness to furnish information along these lines .
 He was subsequently contacted on eight occasions between March 11, 1959, and October 2, 1959 . He furnished no information whatever and further contacts with him were discontinued .
 Ruby was never paid any money, and he was never at any time an informant of this Bureau . Ruby was not an informant, and was never a paid informant, FBI says .
 The Commission failed to see the significance of the nine meetings between the FBI and Ruby during the very time he was trying to free mob boss Trafficante . The Commission also did not bother to question the FBI agent who had met with Ruby .
 Many law-enforcement officers, both state and federal, have privately stated that both the frequency and duration of these contacts suggests there was more to the relationship than Hoover would admit . Hoover would have denied the allegations .
 The House Select Committee on Assassinations did interview Charles W Flynn, the FBI agent who met with Ruby . Flynn was interviewed by the committee on the Ruby case .

 The Mannlicher-Carcano rifle was manufactured in Italy from 1891 until 1941 . In the 1930’s Mussolini ordered all arms factories to manufacture the rifle . Mussolini also ordered all factories to make the rifle in Italy .
 The serial number appears on weapons manufactured by more than one concern . Since many concerns were manufacturing the same weapon, the serial number has been added to the weapon .
 There could be more Carcanos around with serial number C2766 —a fact that further weakens the case against Oswald .

 Another important piece of evidence involved a paraffin test made on Oswald the day of the assassination . The test was made by a paraqualine test made by Oswald on the day he was killed .
 The results of this test presented evidence that he may not have fired a rifle that day, yet these results were downplayed and even suppressed by the federal authorities . The results were presented in court .
 In this test, layers of paraffin are applied to a suspect’s skin and the sticky, warm wax opens the pores and then picks up any foreign material that may be present on the skin .
 When the wax cools, it forms a hard cast that is treated with chemicals that turn blue if nitrates are present . When the cast is cooled, the wax turns blue if there are nitrates present .
 The skin of someone who has recently fired a weapon will bear traces of nitrates . The idea is that the skin of a person who has fired a gun will bear nitrate traces . The skin will be tested for the presence of nitrate .
 The presence of nitrates is not conclusive evidence that a gun was fired . The absence of nitrate is compelling evidence that the person has not fired a weapon .
 Oswald’s hands both reacted positively to the paraffin test, indicating the presence of nitrates but no gunpowder . Oswald's hands were found to have reacted positively . The test was carried out by a team of doctors and nurses .
 Any competent defense attorney would have pointed to this test as evidence that his client had not fired a rifle . The test would have been used to prove that he had not shot a rifle, a defense attorney said .
 The Warren Commission called the routine police test “completely unreliable,” adding that an FBI agent fired three rounds through the Oswald rifle in rapid succession and tested negative on both his hands and face afterward . However, in its report the Warren Commission said the test was "completely unreliable"
 The Commission deleted reference to the paraffin test at the bottom of the page of the evidence sheet . The odd part of this issue is that in publishing the Dallas police evidence sheet, the Commission deleted the reference .
 A fingerprint is the most important piece of evidence linking the crime to the suspect, police say . The fingerprint was used to help identify the person responsible for the crime in the case .
 The sole piece of hard evidence linking Oswald to the Carcano rifle was a palm print . Palm print reportedly found on the underside of the barrel when disassembled .
 The palm print would never have been admitted as evidence in any courtroom trial . It lacked a chain of evidence, the unquestioned path from discovery to presentation in court .
 Dallas police lieutenant John Carl Day says he discovered the palm print shortly before turning the rifle over to the FBI .
 He mentioned it to no one and there is no record of his discovery . Yet, he mentioned no one .
 FBI agent Vincent Drain flew with the gun to Washington in an Air Force plane . About midnight, the rifle was given to Drain, who flew with it to D.C.
 The rifle was turned over to the FBI laboratory on November 23, 1963 . It was examined for fingerprints by the FBI .
 Oswald was killed in the basement of the Dallas police station on November 24 . Oswald's rifle was flown back to Dallas that afternoon . Oswald was shot dead that morning .

 The incriminating palm print did not arrive at the FBI lab until November 29 . It arrived three days after all other Dallas police evidence had been turned over to the bureau . The palm print was not officially turned over by the FBI .
 By this time, FBI officials were able to confirm that the palm print matched that of Lee Harvey Oswald . Oswald's palm print was confirmed to be that of Oswald .
 Day told author Henry Hurt that he specifically pointed out the print to Agent Drain when he gave him the rifle . Day told the author that he told him the print was on his rifle .

 Others believe Oswald’s palm print was taken from jail records or the Depository . Others believe it was superimposed over marks from the barrel .
 No serious researcher today believes that Oswald’s palm print was legitimately lifted from the rifle barrel on November 22, 1963 . Oswald's palm print is believed to have been removed from the barrel of the rifle .
 Even the Warren Commission found this piece of evidence hard to swallow . The Warren Commission was skeptical of the evidence .
 Rankin advised because of the circumstances that now exist, there was a serious question in the minds of the commission as to whether or not the palm impression that has been obtained from the Dallas Police Department is a legitimate latent palm impression removed from the rifle barrel .
 The FBI attempted to have Lieutenant Day certify a statement concerning his lifting of the palm print, but Day declined to sign it . The FBI then attempted to get Lieutenant Day to sign a statement .
 It instead presented the belated palm print as strong evidence of Oswald’s guilt . It was presented as strong proof of Oswald's guilt . The palm print was found in Oswald's pocket in the book .
 The closer one looks, the softer it becomes. Like so much of the “hard’s evidence in this case, the closer look the closer it becomes . The evidence in the case is the "hard" evidence, but it's not hard enough to convict .
 Now consider the highly technical studies of this bullet and other bullet fragments involved in the assassination . Now consider a highly technical study of the bullet fragments .
 Similar ammunition fired into goat carcasses, human bodies, and gelatin blocks all showed more deformity than Commission Exhibit 399 .
 Forensic pathology panel of the House Select Committee on Assassinations argued that other bullets had done similar damage and remained in pristine condition . Panel members of the committee said other bullet damage had been done similar .
 Cyril Wecht challenged the group to produce even one single bullet that had broken two human bones and remained unchanged . Cyril. Wecht, challenged them to produce a bullet that broke two bones . The group produced the bullet that remained unchanged, but the bullet did not break two human
 Neither the Warren Commission nor the House Select Committee on Assassinations was able to convincingly prove the feat ascribed to Commission Exhibit 399 . The emission spectrography tests assume more importance .
 These spectrographic tests are a scientific means of determining whether the various bits of bullet metal taken from both Kennedy and Connally came from the same bullet .
 These tests could have provided what is missing from all Kennedy assassination investigations . Metal found in the victims could be traced to Commission Exhibit 399, Commission Exhibit .
 The tests failed to do this and the handling of this evidence raised a great deal of suspicion toward federal authorities . The tests were supposed to show that federal authorities had done nothing wrong with the case .
 Under such testing it is a simple matter to determine whether two bits of metal have the same percentage of basic elements, such as lead, copper, and antimony . Under such tests, the metal has a higher percentage of the basic elements .
 It is much more difficult to prove that such bits are from the same source. It is more difficult than to prove such bits were not from same source .
 The Warren Commission chose not to ask one question of the spectrographic expert who conducted the tests . Concerning the tests, the Warren Commission did not ask one single question .
 Police say bullet fragments were “similar in metallic composition,” which proved nothing . They were content to simply report that several bullet fragments had similar metallic composition .
 In the years following the assassination, researcher Harold Weisberg sought unsuccessfully to obtain the spectrographic test results from the U.S. government . The results of the test were never found .
 Government attorneys argued that revealing the results was not in the “national interest,” although they would not explain why . Government attorneys said the results would not be in the national interest .
 In 1973, a batch of Warren Commission documents were released to the public that contained letters from FBI director J Edgar Hoover . Then in 1973, the public was allowed to see the letters from Hoover .
 The fact that differences—no matter how “significant”—were found means they are not from the same source . Differences are significant differences, no matter how significant .
 The real significance in this matter is that the results of these spectrographic tests have been kept from the public all these years, says the author of the book .
 By concealing the test results, the Commission raised further suspicion about government handling of the case .
 Unreported in the Commission’s report or volumes was an account of even further testing, this time using neutron activation analysis . This time, the test object was bombarded with radiation .
 This wording is suspiciously deceptive, since any difference in composition is evidence that the fragments are not from the same ammunition . This wording suggests that the ammunition fragments are different from one to one, not the same .
 Faced with scientific evidence that Kennedy and Connally were not struck by the same bullet, the House Select Committee on Assassinations decided to conduct its own tests .
 Guinn admitted he had been an informal consultant to the FBI even prior to the Kennedy assassination . Guinn said he was a consultant with the FBI prior to Kennedy's assassination .
 Guinn concluded that it was ‘highly probable’ that fragments taken from Connally’s wrist came from Commission Exhibit 399 . Guinn concludes that it is “highly likely’t” that the fragments were taken from the wrist .
 The wrist fragments originally tested in 1964 were missing . But it was later learned that the wrist fragments were missing from the original test .
 Guinn admitted publicly that the fragments he tested were not the originals from the National Archives . Guinn said he tested the fragments and admitted they were not originals . The fragments were not from the original National Archives documents .
 Guinn also reported that he had examples of ammunition from the four production runs in 1954 made at Western Cartridge Company, manufacturers of the Mannlicher-Carcano bullets .
 If this was indeed the only ammunition ever produced, the results of Guinn’s tests gain credibility .
 At the end of the war the Italian Carcano rifle, and no telling how much of this type of ammunition, was sold to United States gun brokers and dealers . It was distributed by direct sales to wholesalers, retailers and individual purchasers .
 If the ammunition supposedly used in the Oswald rifle came from this World War II batch, Dr. Oswald would be the first person to claim to have used it in the rifle .
 This is another example of how seemingly indisputable evidence in the assassination diminishes upon closer examination . This is one of many examples of the assassination of JFK's assassin John Kennedy .

 If this bag indeed belonged to Oswald and if it could be traced to the Depository, it becomes strong evidence of Oswald’s guilt . The bag is believed to have been found in the trunk of the Texas State Department .
 This piece of evidence becomes highly questionable . But again, upon closer inspection, the evidence becomes more questionable . CNN.com will feature iReport .

 The FBI found no traces of paper bag particles on the rifle . The rifle was found to have been hit by a paper bag .

 Oswald took a paper bag to work with him on the morning of the assassination . Both Wesley Frazier and his sister, Linnie Mae Randle, testified that Oswald took the paper bag .
 Both said they did not believe the bag they saw was like the one the Warren Commission showed them . However, both said they do not believe it was the one they saw .

 This whole issue is further clouded by a duplicate FBI report that claims two opposite facts concerning the paper bag . The paper bag was used to smuggle drugs into the U.S. State Department .
 In 1980, researcher Gary Shaw discovered what appeared to be this same FBI report in the National Archives . Shaw discovered the report in 1980, and it was later found in archives .

 Not one of the lawmen who searched the Depository mentioned finding the bag in their testimony . The evidence of the paper bag must be viewed skeptically .
 Recall the two days that all assassination evidence was in the hands of the FBI unbeknownst to the media and public . The FBI was involved in the assassination of President George W. Bush .
 Two other observations should be made concerning primary pieces of evidence—the presidential limousine and the rifle . The limo and rifle are the two primary items of evidence in the case .
 Even while the limousine was parked at the emergency-room door of Parkland Hospital, federal agents and even Dallas police apparently mopped up blood, picked up bullet fragments, and otherwise tampered with this important evidence .
 White House photographer Cecil Stroughton noticed agents at the limousine . White House limo was stopped by agents in the limo .
 The limousine was shipped to the manufacturer Hess & Eisenhardt and completely dismantled, thus destroying any important bloodstains, bullet holes, or more bullet fragments that could have shed light on the assassination .
 Government agents examined the car the day after the assassination, but there is no evidence that members of the Warren Commission closely studied this important piece of evidence, including photographs of a bullet or fragment strike on the windshield .
 The Carcano was never given the simple test by Dallas police or federal authorities to determine whether it had been recently fired . It was never checked for fingerprints, apparently .
 This normal testing might have proved conclusively whether the rifle had been used in the assassination . It might have shown conclusively that the rifle was used .
 Researchers view the failure to conduct such a test as strong evidence of fabrication in the case against Oswald . Oswald was convicted of murdering himself in August 1963 .

 The famous backyard photographs showed Oswald with a rifle and a communist publication . Oswald was the one piece of evidence that did more than all others to convict Oswald as the assassin .

 An objective viewing of the three available backyard photographs reveals internal problems aplenty . An objective . viewing of these three . photographs reveals . internal problems .
 All three pictures were reportedly taken with a handheld camera . Background of all three is identical when brought to the same size . All three were taken with handheld cameras .
 The elements of the background are exactly identical in the three photos . That is, though cropped differently in three photos, the background is exactly identical .
 This sameness of background could possibly be produced with a stationary camera on a heavy tripod but is impossible with a handheld camera . The sameness is possible with a tripod but impossible with handheld camera.
 The V-shaped shadow under Oswald’s nose remains the same in all three pictures, although his head is tilted in different directions . Oswald's head was tilted in the different directions, but his eyes are tilted in other directions .
 The photos all show a discernible line marking a break in the print's emulsion across Oswald’s face just above a flat, broad chin . The photos were taken from a print print print of Oswald's face .
 Oswald had a sharply pointed, cleft chin, Dallas police photos show . Oswald was known to have had a sharp, pointed chin . Oswald had been shot dead in Dallas, Texas, in August .
 Oswald’s assessment that the photos are superimposed fakes has been confirmed by two foreign authorities . When all three photos are brought to the same size and placed on top of each other as transparencies, nothing matches except the face of Lee Harvey Oswald Oswald .
 The shadow of Oswald’s nose falls in one direction and that of his body in another . The shadow was the shadow of his nose . Oswald's body was in the shadows of the assassin .
 The photos were shot from a slightly different angle, a different distance, with the gun in a different hand . The photos are taken from a different angle .
 If one photo is laid on top of another, nothing could match exactly . So, if one photo was laid over top, nothing would match exactly.
 While one body is bigger, in the other the heads match perfectly, bearing out Oswald’s charge that his head was pasted on an incriminating photograph . Yet, impossibly, while one body . is bigger than the other, the heads .

 The Photographic Evidence Panel of the House Select Committee on Assassinations concluded in 1978 that it could find no evidence of fakery in the backyard photos . The panel also studied the original photos .
 This conclusion rested primarily on studies that showed markings on the edges of the negative of one of the original photographs were identical to markings on other photographs made by the Imperial Reflex camera .
 Ballistics-type evidence convinced the panel that the photos must be genuine . This ballistics-style evidence convinced them to believe the photos were genuine .
 Texas graphics expert Jack White pointed out that if a knowledgeable person wanted to fake the pictures, it would have been a simple matter to produce a high-quality montage photograph using one backyard scene, a figure with rifle and papers, and a head shot of Oswald . White said that if
 This procedure would produce a faked backyard photo that could be proven to have come from the camera traced to Oswald . Oswald's photo could be faked to produce a photo that was traced to him .
 The Imperial Reflex camera can be used to capture the markings on the edge but nothing else . Another method to achieve the same results would be to make an exposure through the Imperial Reflex . White says he has no idea how to get the results .
 When the composite photo is combined with this, the markings become part of the negative . Then, when the photo is added to the negative, it becomes a composite photo .
 House experts measured distances between certain objects in the pictures . They determined some differences in distance indicated that the photos were separate shots .
 White argued that differences were simply the result of “keystoning” or tilting the easel on which the photograph was exposed in an enlarger . White, who died in 2012, argued that these differences were the result from ‘keysting’
 He said he, too, had been concerned with what appeared to be differences in the photos but discovered that by tilting the photographic print in an enlarger’s easel, the backgrounds of the supposedly separate pictures overlapped and matched .
 White discovered other problems with the backyard photos in recent years . White also discovered other issues with the photos .
 In one picture, the tips of Oswald’s fingers appear to be missing as does one end of the telescopic sight . The tips of the fingers are also missing in one picture of the rifle .

 At least two of the participants have questioned the results of these reenactments .
