 The federal government, led by president Lyndon Johnson, began to assert itself immediately following Kennedy’s death . The Warren Commission was led by Lyndon Johnson .
 All evidence was removed from Dallas that night and sent to FBI headquarters in Washington . Against normal procedure, all evidence was sent to Washington .
 The day after the assassination, despite tremendous confusion in Dallas and elsewhere, FBI director J Edgar Hoover forwarded to Johnson a preliminary report supporting the idea of Lee Harvey Oswald’s sole guilt . Hoover forwarded the preliminary report to Johnson .
 At this time, only selected FBI officials had seen all the evidence . The plausible suspicion of fabrication and substitution grew . The suspect was later found dead at the scene of a car crash .
 Dallas police were being held responsible for Oswald’s death . Calls increased for an independent investigation independent from that of the Dallas police .
 Katzenbach is having something issued so we can convince the public that Oswald is the real assassin . Katzenberg, is having a statement issued to convince people that Oswald was the assassin, he says .
 On November 25, President Johnson ordered his friend Hoover to prepare a detailed report on the circumstances surrounding Kennedy’s death . Hoover's report was released on November 25 .
 It is important that all of the facts surrounding President Kennedy’s assassination be made public in a way which will satisfy people in the U.S. and abroad, says President Kennedy .
 That all the facts have been told and that a statement to this effect be made now. That all of the facts were told, he said . A statement was made now, he added .
 The public must be satisfied that Oswald was the assassin, he did not have confederates who are still at large . The evidence was such that he would have been convicted at trial, the public should have been satisfied .
 Speculation about Oswald’s motivation ought to be cut off . We should have some basis for rebutting the thought that this was a communist conspiracy or a rightwing conspiracy to blame it on the communists .
 Dallas Police have put out statements on the communist conspiracy theory, and it was they who were in charge when he was shot and thus silenced . The Dallas Police are in charge of the Dallas Police .
 The matter has been handled thus far with neither dignity nor conviction . Facts are mixed with rumor and speculation . Facts and speculation have been mixed into rumor .
 We can scarcely let the world see us totally in the image of the Dallas Police when our President is murdered, says President Obama . We can't be seen as police officers in image of Dallas Police, Obama says .
 I think this objective may be satisfied and made public as soon as possible with the completion of a thorough FBI report on Oswald and the assassination . The objective of making public the assassination is to be satisfied with the FBI report .
 This may run into the difficulty of pointing to inconsistency between this report and statements by Dallas Police officials . But the reputation of the Bureau is such that it may do the whole job .
 The only other step would be the appointment of a Presidential Commission of unimpeachable personnel to review the evidence and announce its conclusions .
 I think it can await publication of the FBI report and public reaction to it here and abroad . The FBI report is expected to be published in the next week .
 Texas attorney general Waggoner Carr announced he planned to conduct a court of inquiry concerning the deaths of both Kennedy and Oswald . Also announced on November 25, Carr said he planned an inquiry into Kennedy's death .
 Carr named two prominent Texas attormeys as special counsel for the probe . Carr named Leon Jaworski and Dean Storey, who went on to become the special Watergate prosecutor .
 The next day, Senator Everett Dirksen announced that a Senate investigation of the assassination would be conducted by a special committee headed by James O Eastland, chairman of the powerful Judiciary Committee . The committee was headed by Senator James OEastland .
 The House of Representatives announced an attempt to create yet another investigative committee the next day . Not to be outdone by the Senate, the House also announced a proposal to create a new committee .
 The grief-stricken attorney general, Robert Kennedy, was never consulted about any of these attempts . Robert Kennedy was not consulted on any of the attempts .
 Next-ranking officials met with Johnson’s close friend attorney Abe Fortas . Fortas had blocked the 1948 election investigation of Johnson by obtaining a court order from Supreme Court Justice Hugo Black .
 Yale law professor Eugene Rostow, secretary of state Dean Rusk, and columnist Joseph Alsop convinced President Johnson that a Texas investigation was an attempt to cover up the crimes in Johnson’s home state . These men, all members of the elitist Council on Foreign Relations
 They argued a national commission headed by men of supposedly unimpeachable integrity was needed . They argued that national commission should be needed .
 With the creation of the Warren Commission, Johnson blocked any congressional investigations . Texas attorney general Carr had announced postponement of his state board of inquiry . The next week, the state attorney general announced postponing of his own state board .
 A Gallup poll taken the first week of December 1963 showed a majority of respondents—52 percent—continued to believe that Oswald had not acted alone . Despite massive media coverage of Oswald’s arrest, his slaying, and the amount of evidence offered to the public by both Dallas and
 Rumors were widespread in Texas that Johnson in some way had a hand in the assassination . Rumors of Johnson's involvement in JFK assassination were widespread .
 Warren was born March 19, 1891, in Los Angeles and Bakersfield, California . Warren was the son of Scandinavian immigrants and was born in 1891 . Warren is a best-selling author in California .
 His law practice was interrupted by World War I . After enlisting as an infantry private, Warren was accepted for officer training and became a lieutenant .
 The Armistice was signed before Lieutenant Warren could leave the U.S. Lieutenant Warren was able to return to the United States .
 After the war, Warren became an assistant attorney for the City of Oakland and later a member of the district attorney’s staff . Warren was an assistant lawyer for the city of Oakland .
 By the late 1920s, he had married Nina Palmquist Meyers and was elected as one of the nation’s youngest district attorneys . He was elected in the 1920s as a district attorney .
 Warren easily won reelection in 1930 . Building a reputation for honesty, hard work, and court convictions, he was a successful politician .
 In the late 1930s, Warren campaigned for and won the office of California attorney general . Warren won the title of California's attorney general in the late 1940s .
 Republican Warren is in a heated contest with the California Democratic governor Culbert Olson . Almost immediately, Republican Warren was in the race .
 After Pearl Harbor, Olson proclaimed a state of emergency in California . This conflict reached a breaking point when the war broke out in 1941 . Olson declared the emergency after Pearl Harbor .
 As attorney general, Warren challenged his authority to do so . Shortly afterward, Warren declared himself a candidate for governor . Warren challenged the authority of the attorney general to hold office .
 In a surprising upset, Warren was elected governor of California in late 1942 by more than 342,000 votes . Warren was a surprise upset to Roosevelt and the Democrats were still in firm control nationally .
 In 1946, Warren handily won reelection as governor and began to look toward Washington . Warren won reelection in 1946 and began looking to Washington .
 He may have actually been relieved when the team was defeated by Truman in the greatest upset victory in American politics . Truman may have been relieved by the team's defeat .
 Still hoping for national office, Warren announced he would seek the GOP presidential nomination in 1952 . Warren announced in 1952 that he would run for the Republican presidential nomination .
 He was chagrined to quickly find himself pitted against the war hero Dwight “Ike” Eisenhower . He was soon pitted against Eisenhower .
 Richard Nixon, who had signed a pledge to support Warren, nevertheless began to campaign for Eisenhower, hoping for the vice presidential nomination that he indeed later received . Richard Nixon's campaign was a success for Eisenhower .
 Nixon, who had been in public office for only six years, was the nation’s number-two man . Nixon was in office for six years. Nixon was the president of the United States .
 Nixon feared Warren's clout in the next election . Warren had been a strong contender and Nixon feared his clout . Warren was a strong candidate for president .
 Nixon badgered Eisenhower to find a suitable appointment for Governor Warren which would effectively separate him from his electoral constituency . Nixon wanted Warren to be separate from his constituency .
 Chief Justice Fred Vinson suddenly died in September 1953 . The ideal solution was to fill a Supreme Court vacancy . Chief Justice Vinson died suddenly .
 Warren, who already had decided not to seek a fourth term as governor, was offered the prized seat and accepted . Warren was offered a coveted seat and, to Nixon’s delight, accepted . Nixon's delight is Warren's decision not to run for another term .
 Warren made initial decisions as chief justice that tended to support the status quo . Warren was new on the job and with the naive Eisenhower years as a backdrop .
 As he grew more comfortable in his position, his decisions began to reflect the progressive policies he advocated as California governor . But as he became more comfortable, he began to embrace progressive policies .
 It was under Warren’s leadership that the Supreme Court ruled on the touchy desegregation issues raised by Brown Board of Education of Topeka, Kansas .
 Using private discussions as well as judicial conferences, Warren was able to guide the court to its unanimous decision in Brown . Brown paved the way for racial equality in the United States .
 Brown was a landmark decision and one that caused archconservatives to begin a campaign of bitter attacks against the chief justice . Brown's decision was one of the most controversial decisions in the history of the Supreme Court .
 Later court opinions dealing with the rights of accused persons and the persecution of suspected communists added further fuel to the fires of Warren’s opponents . Warren's opponents say he was unfairly persecuted .
 In the 1960s, Warren voted for young Kennedy, apparently because he could not bring himself to vote for the ever-ambitious Nixon . In the squeaky-close election of 1960, Warren found himself voting for Kennedy .
 Kennedy voiced mutual respect for each other and the new president supported the Warren Court’s progressive activism, even in such controversial cases as the June 1963 decision that outlawed compulsory prayer in public schools . Warren and Kennedy had mutual respect .

 Commission members saw their work as having a dual purpose: to find the facts of the Kennedy assassination . The other was to calm public fears and suspicions both at home and abroad . Commission members say they wanted to find out the truth of the assassination .

 The Single-Bullet Theory Nowhere was the manipulation of the facts more evident than the idea that both President Kennedy and Governor Connally were struck by the same bullet .

 To disbelieve the single-bullet theory means rejecting the Warren Commission’s entire version of the assassination . Yet, to disbelieve it means rejecting Warren Commission's entire version, the author says .

 The original FBI and Secret Service reports made it clear that Kennedy was struck in the back by the first shot . Governor Connally was hit by the second shot, and the president’s head wound caused by the third .

 Ferrie often was seen in the company of Sergio Archaca-Smith, New Orleans director of the virulently anti-Castro Cuban Democratic Revolutionary Front . In 1961, Ferrie was seen with Archaca Smith, director of an anti-Cuba group .
 Ferrie was one of the pilots involved in the ill-fated Bay of Pigs Invasion . That same year, he was introduced to a meeting of the New Orleans Civic Club . Ferrie is a member of the N.O. civic club .
 He also made an anti-Kennedy talk to the New Orleans chapter of the Military Order of World Wars . He said Kennedy "double-crossed" the invasion force by failing to authorize needed air support .
 Ferrie's speech was so vitriolic that several members of the audience walked out . Ferrie’s speech was a vitriolic speech that left several people in the audience walking out .

 On February 22, 1967, David Ferrie was found dead in his cluttered apartment . He was the chief suspect in Garrison's murder investigation .
 Ferrie’s nude body had been discovered lying on a living-room sofa surrounded by prescription medicine bottles, several completely empty . Ferrie's nude body was discovered lying in a living room surrounded by empty prescription bottles .

 The New Orleans coroner ruled that Ferrie died from “natural causes,” specifically a ruptured blood vessel in the brain . Three days later, Ferrie's death was ruled "natural causes," the coroner ruled .
 Garrison checked the empty medicine bottles found near Ferrie's body . One contained a drug designed to greatly increase a person’s metabolism . The drug was found in one bottle .
 A physician friend confirmed to Garrison that if someone suffering from hypertension took a whole bottle of this specific drug, it would cause death very quickly .
 No blood samples or spinal fluid from Ferrie’s autopsy had been retained, Garrison wrote . Garrison later wrote, “I phoned immediately but was told that no blood samples had been kept .”

 Garrison gamely moved ahead with his prosecution of Clay Shaw . Despite the media attacks and missing witnesses, Garrison continued his prosecution .

 Insurance salesman Perry Russo repeated his 1967 statements that he was present when Shaw and Ferrie talked about assassinating Kennedy . Russo says he was in the room at the time of the assassination .

 Assistant district attorney James L Alcock tried to discredit Andrews’s testimony . It appeared he was impeaching the core of Garrison's allegation that Shaw and Bertrand were one and the same .
 Clay Shaw, the respected director of the International Trade Mart, and Clay Bertrand, the man overheard plotting against Kennedy, were the same man . So the crux of the case came down to whether Clay Shaw was the same person as Bertrand .
 Garrison's strongest piece of evidence was Shaw’s jail card, which showed he used the alias Clay Bertrand . Garrison: Shaw used his jail card to get into trouble . Garrison's team says Shaw's jail card shows he used an alias, but Garrison says he's innocent .

 Garrison’s hole card became New Orleans policeman Aloysius J Habighorst, who filled out the admission form . Shaw was expected to testify that his alias was Clay Bertrand .

 David Shaw made a mockery of the law against lying under oath . Shaw had taken the witness stand and, in his grand and courtly manner, lied under oath, the judge said . Shaw's decision was made automatically .

 Garrison believed President Kennedy was killed for one primary reason—he was working for reconciliation with Soviet Russia and Castro’s Cuba . Garrison: Kennedy was trying to reconcile Russia and Cuba with the Soviet Union .
 To anyone with a grain of intelligence, it should be apparent that John Kennedy was eliminated by forces desiring the continuation of the Cold War . The Kennedy assassination was an artificial conflict draining the assets of and greatly changing the character of our nation .
 The clandestine arm for those Cold War forces was the Central Intelligence Agency . The agency's destructive talents run the gambit from deception to murder .
 They believed sincerely that Kennedy had sold them out to the communists . They believed he had given them the opportunity to live their lives . They said they believed he was selling them out .

 Henry Gonzalez of Texas introduced a House resolution in February 1975 calling for a select committee to study the deaths of Robert Kennedy and Martin Luther King, and the 1972 shooting of Alabama governor George Wallace .
 Gonzalez: "I have introduced this resolution after much consideration" Gonzalez says he introduced the resolution after "much consideration"

 Action stalled in the House for more than a year. Despite these passionate appeals for a reinvestigation into the assassinations, action stalled in House for a year .
 The Gonzalez and Downing bills were merged into House Resolution 1540 and passed in September 1976 . King’s wife, Coretta, put pressure on the House leadership, and the bill passed in 1976 .
 The committee would expire at the end of the congressional term on January 3, 1977 . However, the committee would last until January 3 .
 House tradition dictated that the author of a resolution creating a select committee be named chair . House tradition dictates that a chair of the committee would be chosen by the author .
 Downing, who had not sought reelection in 1976, would soon retire . Gonzalez, a highly individualistic Mexican-American, was not liked by House power brokers . Downing was not re-elected in 1976 . Downing would not seek reelection .
 Downing was named chairman of the House Select Committee on Assassinations by Speaker Thomas P “Tip” O’Neill . Gonzalez, who began to serve as cochairman, did not like the decision .
 Downing wanted Washington attorney Bernard Fensterwald to serve as the committee’s chief counsel and director . Downing wanted him to be the chairman of the committee .
 Fensterwald formed a clearinghouse of assassination material called the Committee to Investigate Assassinations . He was an early critic of the Warren Commission and thoroughly familiar with most aspects of the case .
 Information for this attack came from Gonzalez’s office, officials say . Later it was learned that information from Gonzalez's office came from his office . The attack was the first of its kind .
 Downing and Gonzalez settled on a former Philadelphia prosecutor, Richard A Sprague, as the committee’s chief counsel . Sprague was the committee's chief counsel in 1976 .
 He had a record of sixty-nine convictions out of seventy homicide cases . He was known as a tough and independent prosecutor .
 He had received national attention by his prosecution of United Mine Workers president Tony Boyle for the murder of UMW reformer Joseph Yablonski . Boyle was found guilty of the murder .
 He said these assassination inquiries would be treated as homicide investigations . He said they would be considered homicide investigations by police .
 This was a novel approach to the Kennedy assassination since, until that time, all investigation and deliberation had been conducted in secret by the government . This was the government's first attempt to investigate the assassination .

 The agreement bound the signer not to reveal that he or she even worked for the committee or to reveal anything learned while serving with the committee . It also gave the committee the power to take legal action against the signinger in the event of disclosures, even long after they ended .
 Many persons who have seen this agreement, including attorneys, claim it violates the United States Constitution and therefore is illegal . Lawyers say the agreement violates the U.S. Constitution and is illegal.

 Two separate studies of a Dallas police radio recording reveal evidence that more than one gunman fired on Kennedy in Dallas . Two separate scientific studies of the Dallas police recording revealed evidence of multiple shooting victims .
 More than one assassin was involved in Kennedy’s death, acoustical studies of a Dallas police radio recording indicated . A Dallas police recording indicated that more than one assassination was involved .
 This evidence destroyed the Warren Commission’s theory of a lone gunman . It forced the Assassinations Committee to completely reverse its findings at the last moment .
 A motorcycle officer by the sound of a nearby motorcycle engine opened his microphone about two minutes before the shooting started and left it open for about eight minutes . A Dallas police officer was shot dead by a motorcycle officer .
 In late 1976, Gary Mack obtained a copy of the Dallas police radio recording in the belief that the open microphone had been in Dealey Plaza . Gary Mack, today curator of the Sixth Floor Museum in Dallas, obtained the recording in late 1976 . He believes that the microphone was in De
 He reasoned that if the microphone was indeed open in Dealey Plaza, it must have picked up the sounds of the shots . The microphone must have been open, he said .
 By September 1977, he had enhanced the quality of the tape and concluded that the recording indicated as many as seven shots . The recording was made in 1977 .
 The existence of the police recording became known to the Assassinations Committee . The committee obtained what was thought to be the original recording from a retired Dallas police lieutenant .
 This original recording was turned over to the acoustics firm of Bolt, Beranek & Newman Inc. for sophisticated scientific tests . The original recording—termed a Dictabelt—was turned over for sophisticated tests .
 James Barger, the firm’s chief scientist, converted the sounds on the tape into digitized waveforms to produce a visual picture of the sound .
 Study also looked into ‘sequence of impulses,’ which could distinguish sharp, loud noises such as gunshots from subsequent echoes .
 Barger determined there were at least six such impulses . Barger asked for further tests, including an on-site test in Dealey Plaza .
 By summer 1978, Blakey was aware that the acoustical scientists supported Mack’s contention that the tape showed gunfire from more than one location . Mack: The tape was shot at a number of locations .
 There were as many as nine sounds on the Dallas recording that could not be ruled out as gunshots, acoustical scientists said . In fact, during their public testimony, scientists stated that there were as Many as 9 sounds that could be ruled as gunshots .
 After testing from two locations, they could confirm only four shots from the Grassy Knoll . But after the Dealey Plaza testing, only four confirmed shots were captured .
 The tape showed that one shot came only 1.2 seconds behind another . The tape also showed that the tape showed one of the shots came in 1.5 seconds behind the other .
 The FBI had determined that it required at least 2. seconds to cock and fire the Carcano rifle twice, this was further evidence of more than one assassin . Since the FBI had carefully determined that . it required . at least . 2 seconds to fire the . Carcano . rifle twice
 Blakey shocked committee members with this information, and staff members began to reconsider their conclusions . But not until after the police tape was turned over to yet another team of acoustical scientists for a second opinion .
 Weiss and Aschkenasy agreed with Barger’s findings and also encouraged on-site testing . Weiss: "It's a good idea to have a lot of testing done in the U.S.
 The idea was to create computerized graphic pictures of the sound patterns of rifle shots in Dealey Plaza . The pictures were created to match the patterns discovered in the police recording .

 One pile --apparently representing one of the early shots -- was located in the far left lane . However, one pile was located near the scene of the shooting .

 Dallas police Channel 1 had no AGC circuitry at that time, Mack pointed out . Channel 1 was not equipped with AGC technology .

 In 1999, the King family won a wrongful death civil case in which they claimed King had been the victim of an assassination conspiracy . King's family won the case against Memphis police and federal agencies in 1999 . The King family has a history of racial discrimination .
 This jury verdict affirmed the innocence of James Earl Ray and awarded the King family their sought sum of $100, evidence they were not pursuing financial gain . The King family was awarded $100 after Ray was found guilty .

 The Oliver Stone Film JFK was released in 1991 . The film was released by the already controversial director Oliver Stone .
 The film was a Herculean effort to distill more than a thousand hours of film containing JFK assassination facts and information into slightly more than three hours . The film is based on more than 1,000 hours of JFK assassination footage .
 The film galvanized both sides of the conspiracy argument . Despite being lambasted as “absurd” and “untrue” by the corporate mass media even prior to its release, the film galvanizes both sides .
 Researchers who had been claiming a conspiracy in Kennedy’s death saw vindication in the movie . But lone-assassin advocates held the film up as an exercise in presenting unsupported theories .

 Groody and Baumgartner noticed that the skull of the corpse under examination was in one piece . However, as the forensic examination continued, the skull was completely intact .
 The absence of signs of a craniotomy, a normal autopsy procedure, was confirmed by doctors .
 A craniotomy involves drawing the skin off the human skull and cutting off the top of the skull with a bone saw . It is usually in a V-shaped cut, usually in the shape of a V, in order to cut off the skull .
 There can be no question that this procedure was performed on Oswald’s body since the weight of his brain was recorded in the autopsy report . Oswald's body was recorded as being carried out by his brain .

 In the three-year period that followed the murders of President Kennedy and Lee Harvey Oswald, 18 material witnesses died . Six by gunfire, three in motor accidents, two by suicide, one from a cut throat . Five from natural causes, five from gunshot wounds .
 Actuary: Odds against witnesses being dead by 1967 were one hundred thousand trillion to one . Actuary concluded that on November 22, 1963, the odds against them being dead were 100,000 trillion to 1 .
 The comment on the deaths of assassination witnesses was published in a tabloid companion piece to the movie Executive Action .
 By that time, part of the mythology of the Kennedy assassination included the questionable deaths of people who were connected with it .
 By the mid-1960s, people in Dallas already were whispering about the number of people who died under strange or questionable circumstances . By the 1960s, Dallas had a reputation for strange deaths .
 Well into the 1980s, witnesses and others were hesitant to come forward with information because of the stories of strange and sudden death that seemed to visit some people with information about the assassination .
 The House Select Committee on Assassinations looked into the matter in the late 1970s . The committee felt compelled to look into the case .
 The committee was unable to come to any conclusions regarding the growing number of deaths .
 The committee said it could not make a valid actuarial study due to the broad number and types of people that had to be included in such a study . The committee also said it couldn't make a study that could not be made into a valid study .
 London Sunday Times legal manager Anthony Whitaker backpedaled on the publication’s original statements . Whitaker: "Our piece about the odds against the deaths of the Kennedy witnesses was, I regret to say, based on a careless journalistic mistake"
 The odds against 15 of those included in the Warren Commission Index dying within a given period are much lower . However, if one asks what are the odds against those who have died within that period, the odds are much higher .
 “Our mistake was to treat the reply to the former question as if it dealt with the latter,” he said . “We should have been careful not to treat it as an answer to the question.”
 This settled the matter for the House committee, which apparently made little or no attempt to seriously study the number of deaths that followed the JFK assassination .
 Richard Charnin, who holds a master’s degree in applied mathematics, has provided a detailed analysis of this issue . He is a former numerical control engineer for Grumman Aerospace .
 Charnin argued that the number of JFK-related witnesses is not relevant . He said that the U.S. population is not a factor in the case of JFK witnesses .
 Whitaker neglected to provide unnatural-death mortality statistics . Charnin also pointed out that Whitaker failed to provide natural-death death statistics .
 Analysis will show that the actuary’s calculation was essentially correct . In fact, he claimed that the problem was misstated, implying that the probability calculation was wrong .

 Musen had calculated the odds of 15 people out of 2,479 in the Warren Commission Index dying within a three-year period, assuming a median age of 40, to be 98.16 percent . Musen: "Odds of 15 dying within three years of age are 98

 The odds that at least 15 of 2,479 would die unnaturally within 3 years is one in 46,000 . The odds of 15 deaths in 3 years are one in about half a million .
 At least 33 of 1,400 JFK assassination-related witnesses died unnaturally in the three years following the assassination . Charnin said his analysis countered the “feeble attempts to rebut and obfuscate the actuary’s 100,000 trillion to 1 odds’
 This section has been titled “Convenient Deaths” because these deaths certainly would have been convenient for anyone not wishing the truth of the JFK assassination to become public . This section is titled ‘Convenient deaths’

 The means of eliminating unwanted witnesses certainly existed, both then and now . However, the means of elimination of unwanted witnesses were still available, both now and now.
 CIA technicians revealed a variety of TWEP technology —“Termination With Extreme Prejudice’ — that cannot be detected in a postmortem examination . CIA technicians testified before the Church Committee about CIA improprieties .
 One letter from an agency consultant to a CIA officer listed circumstances under which people could be killed but made to look like natural death, accident, or suicide .
 The letter went on to show that undetected murders do not necessarily have to be the result of sophisticated technology . The letter also said that the murders were not necessarily result of technology .
 It stated, “There are two techniques which I believe should be mentioned since they require no special equipment besides a strong arm and the will to do such a job. It stated .
 These would be either to smother the victim with a pillow or to strangle him with a wide piece of cloth such as a bath towel .
 The C[A has developed drugs to induce cancer, it is less well known that the agency has developed the drugs . The agency has the capability of killing, and hence the mob through operatives .
 Jack Ruby claimed to have been given such a drug just as he was granted a new trial . Ruby claimed the drug was given to him just before his new trial was due to be granted . Jack Ruby was jailed for life in prison for five years for a drug charge .
 Local law-enforcement officers and coroners are not equipped, either by training or inclination, to detect deaths induced by such sophisticated means . Local law enforcement is not equipped to detect such deaths, officials say .
 Police look for signs of a struggle, evidence of a break-in, bruises, or marks on the victim . They look for evidence of break-ins or a struggle .
 With no evidence to the contrary, many deaths are ruled suicide or accident . Many deaths have been ruled either by suicide or accidental .

 As an intelligence agent, he would have followed orders and easily could have been manipulated into incriminating himself as the assassin . He could have easily incriminated himself as an assassin, he said .
 Oswald's position as a spy would have prevented the Russians from proclaiming the truth of the assassination to their world, since they could hardly be expected to admit their knowledge of Oswald . Furthermore, his position as spy would not prevent the truth from being revealed to the world .
 Once the idea of conspiracy is acknowledged, questions of who fired a gun, from what location, and how many times become irrelevant . Questions of who shot a gun become irrelevant in this case .
 Much more important are the questions of who benefited from the assassination and who had the ability to cover up the truth, says CNN's John Sutter .
 It appears there may have been two serious slip-ups for the conspirators . It appears they may have slipped-ups in the process .

 The true assassins simply strolled away, after dumping their rifles into nearby car trunks or passing them to confederates . They dumped them in nearby trunks, or passed them to a confederate .

 The HSCA determined that one shot was fired point-blank into his head, a coup de grace . It was the first time a man was shot in the head by a gunman, a coroner ruled .

 A cover-up began immediately, leaving only his mother to question the official version of the assassination . Only his mother was able to speak out against the government .
 While this scenario can be disputed, it nevertheless represents the only narrative that conforms to all of the known facts . This scenario is disputed, but it nonetheless represents the truth .
 Lyndon B Johnson was sworn in as president within two hours of the assassination . Johnson was the first president to be sworn in in office .
 His first act as president was to violate the laws of his own state by ordering the removal of Kennedy’s body from Parkland Hospital over the objections of the Dallas County medical examiner who was required by law to conduct an inquest .
 By that evening, Johnson was exerting undue influence over the Dallas investigation both directly and through his aides . Johnson's aides say he was influencing the investigation .
 Johnson coerced a reluctant chief justice Earl Warren into heading a special presidential commission charged with finding Oswald alone guilty of the deed . Within two weeks, Johnson had coerced Warren to head a special commission .
 The creation of the Warren Commission effectively blocked several other assassination investigations in both Texas and Washington . The Warren Commission was created in order to prevent other investigations .

 Both agencies, along with the Secret Service, have been officially chastised for concealing evidence from two government investigations . Both agencies have been accused of concealing information from the two government probes .

 Some were simply told to keep quiet while others died under unusual circumstances . Some were told they would not be able to speak out . Others died in mysterious circumstances .

 Usually only one reference is given, though multiple sources may be found in most instances . Usually only references are given, but multiple sources are found .
 Accounts of witnesses sometimes represent a synthesis of their words from more than one source . Accounts of witness accounts sometimes represent synthesis of words from multiple sources .
 It should be pointed out that just because a statement is attributed to some source does not make that statement true . Just because a source quotes a statement doesn't make it true .
 People's accounts can result from mistakes as well as lies due to fear and intimidation . People’s accounts can be made up of mistakes and lies, according to experts .
